PRJNA1420917.title: Bacteria associated with the spoilage of ground beef
PRJNA1420917.description: A total of 180 bacterial strains recovered from ground beef, spoiled or close to spoilage, were sequenced in this study.

PRJNA1333436.title: Cryobacterium sp. AP23 Genome sequencing
PRJNA1333436.description: Development within Arctic regions, much like any other global environment, will lead to the accumulation of waste. These waste products include materials such as petroleum based products (e.g., plastics, fuels, lubricants, etc.), paper based products, and other organic contaminants commonly removed and treated at municipal wastewater treatment plants. The low temperatures in arctic regions represent a significant challenge for established wastewater treatment methods that depend on mesophilic temperatures. Fortunately, cold adapted microbes represent a largely unexploited source of biocatalysts or enzymes for cold environments. Our project seeks to identify novel microbial isolates capable of enhancing waste treatment in low temperature environments.

PRJNA1394536.title: Andes permafrost active layer metagenome
PRJNA1394536.description: The aim of this study was to reveal and compare the microbial taxonomic diversity of the hitherto almost undisturbed and unknown permafrost regions located in different climatic zones of the Andes in Chile.

PRJNA1365190.title: Reconstructing the effects of anthropogenic activities and climate change in three lakes of the Fildes Peninsula, Maritime Antarctic
PRJNA1365190.description: To establish the effect of human activities on Fildes Peninsula lakes, we compared trends in diatom assemblages, bacterial communities (by 16S rRNA gene sequencing) and metal concentrations in sediment cores from two lakes close to human infrastructure with those in a more remote lake.

PRJNA1405953.title: Electric Treatment Effects on Soil Nitrogen-Cycling Microbes
PRJNA1405953.description: This study aims to analyze the composition and diversity of soil nitrogen-cycling microbial communities via 16S rRNA gene sequencing, and to investigate the impacts of electric treatment and different nitrogen fertilization practices on these communities. It further seeks to elucidate how the microbial activities contribute to soil nitrous oxide mitigation. The findings are expected to provide novel microbiological insights for reducing agricultural soil nitrous oxide emissions.
PRJNA1405953.center_name: Beijing Academy of Agriculture and Forestry Sciences

PRJEB106064.description: Complete genome of Serratia plymuthica PAMC22778 isolated from Sediment, Kara sea

PRJEB72025.title: Arctic microbiome along Svalbard Cross Shelf transects (2017 Campaign)
PRJEB72025.description: Microbiome analysis of seawater samples collected at stations along Svalbard Cross Shelf transects (Kongsfjorden and Rijpfjorden), at different depths, based on V4-V5 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing, using Illumina.  Samples were collected during the Norwegian Polar Institute MOSJ-ICE 2017 plankton-monitoring program. Samples were concentrated on board through Sterivex 0.2 mm filtration and preserved at -80ºC for later DNA extraction.  This dataset is part of a standardized effort for a long-term analysis of microbiome data collected at the same geographic locations and with the same methodologies, during different years. Other datasets already publicly available integrated in this long-term effort include MOSJ2016 (MGYS00003725), MOSJ2018, MOSJ2019 and MOSJ2020.
PRJEB72025.center_name: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

PRJEB24517.title: Arctic microbiome along Svalbard Cross Shelf transects (2016 Campaign)
PRJEB24517.description: Global worming and climate change has been manifested in the decrease of the Arctic Ocean see ice extent and thickness. The thinner sea-ice regime that the Arctic has been facing changed Arctic’s primary productivity and biogeochemistry. Understanding the dynamics of the microbial communities that feed Arctic phytoplankton and biologically derived carbon export will be worthwhile in order to draw future trends. In this study we present a comprehensive analysis of the biogeographic patters of Arctic microbiome diversity and distribution along two oceanographic transects in the Marginal Ice Zone around Svalbard, within strong environmental gradients (Ripfjorden, Kongsfjorden). A total of 11 stations were sample at three depths (surface, chlorophyll maximum and bottom) during the Norwegian Polar Institute MOSJ-ICE 2016 plankton-monitoring program. Samples were concentrated on board through Sterivex 0.2 mm filtration and preserved at -80ºC for later DNA extraction. Amplification of 16S rRNA and 18S rRNA genes were performed and sequenced in Illumina MiSeq with a sequence depth of about 100 thousand read pairs. The prokaryotic and eukaryotic MOSJ-ICE16 data sets collection comprises highly complex and diverse microbial communities with a marked biogeographic pattern of distribution. Strong links were identified between bacterioplanckton and phytoplankton/picophytoplankton distribution driven by environmental and biogeochemical forces, most relevant to unravel the role of microbial pathways in supporting Arctic Ocean Primary productivity and system integrity.
PRJEB24517.center_name: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

PRJNA1391519.title: Yoonia sp. MH D7 strain:MH D7 Genome sequencing
PRJNA1391519.description: We report the draft genome sequence of Yoonia sp. nov. MH D7, an Alphaproteobacteria isolated from the surface of the green seaweed Monostroma hariotii collected in King George Island, Antarctica.

PRJNA1258752.title: Microbial community succession during low temperature anaerobic digestion
PRJNA1258752.description: Anaerobic digestion (AD) is a circular approach to managing organic waste as well as producing biogas (renewable energy) and the process by-product, digestate. Digestate arising from low temperature AD harbors microorganisms that are cold-tolerant. This study seeks to investigate microbial succession in response to gradual temperature reduction during AD. Cold-resilient microbes will be identified and their potential applications in improving low temperature AD will be highlighted.
PRJNA1258752.center_name: Agricultural Research Council - Soil, Climate and Water

PRJEB97802.title: Bacterial 16S V4V5 data on 4 permafrost soils inoculated with active layer soils in an aerobic incubation experiment
PRJEB97802.description: The study explores the role of inoculating permafrost soils with active layer microbial communities across four different permafrost types (palsa peat, sedge peat, cryoturbated soil, yedoma). Permafrost soils were either inoculated with active layer soil, a negative control (sterile H2O), or a positive control (microbial community from a temperate grassland soil). DNA was extracted with QIAGEN DNEasy PowerSoil Pro kit before incubation, one day after inoculation and after 389 days of incubation under aerobic settings at 10 degrees C. V4V5 amplicons were generated with 515f-926r primers and sequenced on MiSeq v3 2x300bp with 15% PhiX spike. Deposited amplicons were demultiplexed with Illumina BaseSpace and no other processing was carried out: sequencing adapters and nextera indices are removed, but not the primers.
PRJEB97802.center_name: UiT The Arctic University of Norway

PRJEB74342.title: Permafrost erosion on shallow subsurface sediment at Herschel Island
PRJEB74342.description: The Arctic permafrost has been identified as a critical global tipping element in a warming climate. Coastal permafrost erosion releases between 5 and 14 Tg of organic carbon (OC) annually into the Arctic Ocean. Once discharged into the ocean and redeposited on the ocean floor, the fate of permafrost organic matter remains largely unclear. Despite its significant potential to release previously stored carbon back into the atmosphere, the process is accelerated by anthropogenic climate change. We quantified the dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) composition and microbial community of nearshore sediments off Herschel Island in the Canadian Beaufort Sea. Our data indicate that redeposited permafrost OC can be readily utilized in the subsurface. Considering the tremendous size of the eroding coastal permafrost reservoir even the conservative ~27% contribution may have a long-lasting effect on the global climate, increasing the climate crisis.

PRJEB80389.title: A study about the effect of different preservation methods on the soil microbiome
PRJEB80389.description: The aim of this study is to provide a method for the conservation of soil samples that guarantees the maximum preservation of the taxonomic and functional biodiversity of soil microorganisms. To this end, a metabarcoding approach was applied to both DNA and RNA extracted from soil samples after preservation under different conditions and for different durations. The same approach was also applied to DNA extracted from microorganisms isolated from soil at each time point. The study covers a wide range of microorganisms including archaea, bacteria and fungi through the use of three different couples of primers.

PRJDB36003.title: Differences in bacterial microbiota of smear-ripened cheese inoculated with or without M. psychrotolerans RV-2-3 strain under low temperature storage
PRJDB36003.description: Cheese is a traditional fermented dairy food, with more than 1,000 varieties of distinctive flavors. These flavors were formed by nonstarter microorganisms which are introduced spontaneously from raw materials and cheese making environment. However, due to the diversity and complexity of microbiota and components that constitute ripened cheese, the overall relationship between flavor development and existing microorganisms remains unclear. In this study, bacterial microbiota analysis was conducted on soft-type smear-ripened cheese from Japan, revealing that Marinilactibacillus, which are halophilic and alkaliphilic marine lactic acid bacteria, were predominant. We isolated Marinilactibacillus psychrotolerans RV-2-3 strain from the same smear-ripened cheese used for the bacterial microbiota analysis and performed draft genome sequencing analysis of the strain. Furthermore, smear-ripened cheese was inoculated with the isolated strain, and the fluctuation in bacterial community and metabolite composition under storage conditions was observed, comparing the cheese without the strain.
PRJDB36003.center_name: Department of Bioscience Faculty of Applied Bioscience, Tokyo University of Agriculture

PRJNA1130732.title: Bacteria isolated from Antarctic ice-free soils (Psychrobacillus sp. L3, Psychrobacillus sp. L4, Sporosarcina sp. A2) as well as their bacteriophages Spoks, Perkons, and Lietuvens. Whole genome sequencing and assembly.
PRJNA1130732.description: Sequencing data relevant to the project "Structural and functional studies of proteome encoded by three novel temperate DNA bacteriophages isolated from Antarctic soil" (lzp-2022/1-0111). The sequencing data generated and analyzed within the scope of the project is expected to expand the current knowledge on the diversity of culturable bacteria from Antarctic soils and their phages.Previously, we retrieved three novel temperate bacteriophages and their host bacteria from the Antarctic soil samples collected during the first Latvian Antarctic Expedition. The current project mainly focuses on the elucidation of functions for evolutionarily conserved proteins of unknown function found in the proteome of the Psychrobacillus phage Perkons, Psychrobacillus phage Spoks, and Sporosarcina phage Lietuvens, which are the first cultured phages known to infect the representatives of the aforementioned bacterial genera. The novelty of phages made it interesting to elucidate the genomes of their hosts to enable phage-host interaction studies at a finer scale, as well as to expand the knowledge on the culturable Antarctic bacteria genomic diversity.Within the project, we have planned to perform the RNA sequencing of the phage+host systems at different time points after the infection to temporally resolve the transcriptome of the phages and see how the host responds to the infection. For this, we needed to obtain not only the complete annotated phage genomes (which were already publicly released by us through GenBank several years ago) but also sequence, assemble, and annotate the complete genomes of the host strains for the aforementioned phages. During the course of the project, we will release complete annotated genomes of the aforementioned novel bacterial isolates alongside the relevant Illumina (250 bp PE) and long-read (ONT) datasets that allowed us to assemble these complete genomes that will be annotated using PGAP.This BioProject will be used to make all the relevant sequencing data and assemblies related to this project publicly available without any restriction to reinforce the results and conclusions drawn from the sequencing part of the research performed within the lzp-2022/1-0111 project.
PRJNA1130732.center_name: Latvian Biomedical Research and Study Centre

PRJNA1366496.title: Whole genome sequencing of Staphylococcus spp

PRJNA1385303.title: 16S rRNA sequencing of gut microbiota from active season Arctic ground squirrels fed diets varying in protein amounts
PRJNA1385303.description: This dataset examines the effect of dietary protein content on gut microbial communities in summer-active Arctic ground squirrels (Urocitellus parryii). Male and female squirrels were fed either 9% or 18% protein diets for eight weeks. Cecal and small intestinal lumen and mucosal samples were collected and analyzed using 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing to assess bacterial community diversity and composition. This dataset supports the investigation of how dietary protein availability influences the gut microbial community and its potential role in microbially salvaged urea-nitrogen.

PRJNA1381318.title: Archaeal microbiome from arctic tundra soils
PRJNA1381318.description: Diversity study based on 16S rRNA archaeal gene amplicon sequencing. The goal was to explore the ammonia oxidizing archaea (AOA) communities in arctic tundra soils from the circumpolar region.

PRJNA1370479.title: The microbiome of an invasive Antarctic insect, Eretmoptera murphyi (Diptera: Chironomidae), and its potential role in nutrient cycling
PRJNA1370479.description: Eretmoptera murphyi is a flightless chironomid midge endemic to South Georgia in the sub-Antarctic. In the 1960s it was accidentally introduced to Signy Island (in the maritime Antarctic), where it is now considered an invasive species. This study set out to assess the archaeal and bacterial microbiome of E. murphyi to enhance understanding of the ecological impacts of this non-native species.

PRJNA1362997.title: Impacts of large herbivores on mycorrhizal fungal communities across the Arctic
PRJNA1362997.description: We sampled environmental DNA from soil samples collected in 15 sites around the Arctic in both Ambient and herbivore exclosure conditions. We aimed to evaluate the impact of large mammalian herbivores on mycorrhizal fungal relative abundance using both a general ITS primer set and an AM specific primer set. We also evaluated the effects of soil properties, climate conditions, and plant functional types on the mycorrhizal fungal communities.These raw sequence reads are submitted to support the accepted Brachmann et al. Ecography manuscript of the same title.

PRJNA1333610.title: Microbes from the Gilkey Glacier, Alaska
PRJNA1333610.description: Alaskan mountain glaciers are experiencing significant mass loss. With solar radiation being a primary driver of melting glacial ice and snow, glaciers and high-elevation mountain snowpacks are especially sensitive to changes in the concentration of light absorbing particles. Impurities such as mineral dust, black carbon, microbes and organic matter have been shown to reduce the surface albedo, increasing the absorption of solar radiation and accelerating melt to downstream ecosystems. Partnering with the Juneau Icefields Research Program we isolated and sequenced microbes from the Gilkey Glacier, Alaska.

PRJNA1340731.title: Low-Temperature Two-Stage Liquid Fermentation
PRJNA1340731.description: Our study addresses a critical challenge in animal nutrition: the persistence of antinutritional factors in complete feeds that limit digestibility and impair animal health. We developed a low-temperature two-stage fermentation strategy, employing Bacillus subtilis during the aerobic phase and Lactobacillus plantarum during the anaerobic phase. This process markedly degraded soybean antigenic proteins and crude fiber, enhanced protein content and enzymatic activity, and inhibited the accumulation of harmful biogenic amines.High-throughput 16S rRNA sequencing confirmed that this fermentation strategy promoted a shift toward beneficial microbial dominance while suppressing pathogenic taxa. Collectively, these findings demonstrate that two-stage fermentation not only improves the nutritional and functional quality of pig feed but also ensures microbial safety.

PRJNA1356905.title: Translationally active cells in the Guaymas Basin deep biosphere
PRJNA1356905.description: The marine deep biosphere spans the entire global ocean and offers a wide range of environmental conditions for microbes to flourish. However, the identities and metabolic functions of these microbial populations are not well understood. In this study, we investigate translationally active microbial communities and elucidate their metabolic activity in hydrothermally impacted marine sediments. By combining activity measurements, amplicon sequencing, and metagenomics data, we improved our understanding of carbon transformations and microbial ecology of the deep biosphere. Our findings emphasize the ecological significance of heterotrophic microbes and the carbon-degrading metabolisms they use to survive in extreme conditions. This work advances the applications of next-generation physiology techniques to document single-cell metabolic activity in a high-throughput manner in the marine deep biosphere.

PRJNA1245678.title: Bacterial and fungal leaf microbiome in mountain avens (Dryas octopetala): comparison of Arctic and Alpine regions
PRJNA1245678.description: This study aims to investigate the differences in the fungal and bacterial microbiome between Dryas octopetala found in the Tatra Mountains, Poland and Spitsbergen, Norway. The material was collected from five locations in the Tatra Mountains, Poland and five locations in Spitsbergen, Norway. Leaves were surface sterilized, total genomic DNA was isolated, and PCR reactions amplifying the 16S rRNA gene and ITS region were performed. Amplicons were sequenced using the Oxford Nanopore MinION platform. Reads with mean Q scores lower than 9 were filtered out in parallel with base-calling on the MinKNOW (v2023.06.13) program using Guppy v3.2.10.
PRJNA1245678.center_name: Institute of Plant Genetics, Polish Academy of Sciences

PRJNA1353130.title: Plant and soil microbiome following glacier retreat
PRJNA1353130.description: Glaciers are retreating at an accelerating rate due to global climate warming, profoundly reshaping alpine landscapes. As ice recedes, newly exposed forelands become natural laboratories to study primary succession and ecosystem development. These environments offer unique opportunities to understand how biodiversity colonizes and functions in response to rapid environmental change. In particular, glacier retreat has far-reaching consequences for microbial and plant communities and, consequently, for ecosystem processes such as nutrient cycling and soil formation.In this project, we investigated how glacier retreat influences fungal and bacterial communities and their interactions with plants along a chronosequence spanning approximately 160 years of deglaciation. We sampled bulk soil, rhizosphere soil, and root endosphere from multiple plant species across four stages of deglaciation. Unlike many studies that focus on single plant species, we adopted a community-level approach, encompassing a broad diversity of co-occurring alpine plants to better capture the complexity of plant-microbe associations in these dynamic systems.Our study aimed to (1) characterize the composition and diversity of bacterial and fungal communities across different plant microhabitats (soil, rhizosphere, roots), (2) assess how these communities change along the temporal and spatial gradient of glacier retreat, and (3) reconstruct plant-bacteria and plant-fungi interaction networks to identify key drivers of microbial community assembly and ecosystem functioning. We examined both alpha-diversity (within-sample diversity) and beta-diversity (between-sample variation), as well as the distribution of functional groups associated with different stages of succession. We analyzed a total of 234 microbial communities using high-throughput sequencing approaches, enabling detailed insights into how microbial diversity and function evolve over time and space.Although soil microorganisms play a foundational role in ecological processes and ecosystem functions, they are often overlooked in conservation measures. It is therefore important to understand their fate in fast-changing environments, especially before the extinction of glaciers leads to their disappearance from Earth. Our study contributes to filling this knowledge gap by providing an integrative view of plant-microbe interactions along a glacier foreland. The results underscore the need to consider microbial communities in ecological models and conservation frameworks addressing the impacts of climate change on alpine ecosystems.

The bacterium's enzymes and its genomic information have been studied to understand its adaptation to cold environments and for biotechnological applications, such as in wine analysis.

PRJNA1333693.title: A Novel Mechanism of Sea-Surface-Microlayer Formation Driven by Terrestrial Runoff: A Source of Ice Nucleating Particles in Arctic Coastal Environments
PRJNA1333693.description: Biological aerosols serve as efficient ice-nucleating particles (INPs), driving the liquid-to-ice transition in clouds and thereby shaping cloud thickness, lifetime, albedo, and precipitation. Although atmospheric INPs are known to derive from terrestrial, freshwater, and marine environments, their specific sources and microbial producers remain largely unresolved, especially in the rapidly warming Arctic. Here, we examine terrestrial runoff as a driver of INP enrichment during summer in Young Sound fjord, Northeast Greenland. INP concentrations active at -10 degC, were significantly elevated in the sea-surface microlayer (SML) and at river outlets relative to bulk seawater, correlating positively with freshwater input and negatively with salinity and distance from runoff. These patterns highlight terrestrial runoff as a major source of warm-temperature INPs. We further identify a novel mechanism of SML formation in Arctic coastal waters: direct accumulation of terrestrial particles and compounds at the surface due to density contrasts between fresh and seawater. Highly active biological INPs were also observed in the atmosphere (1.3-25.3 INP-10 m-3), with sequencing data suggesting terrestrial origins. Our findings demonstrate how terrestrial ecosystems enrich the coastal SML with biogenic INPs that are subsequently aerosolized, underscoring their importance for Arctic cloud processes under ongoing climate change.

PRJNA1330136.title: 16S rRNA gene sequencing of soils along a two-year recovery gradient after low-temperature thermal desorption remediation
PRJNA1330136.description: This dataset contains the raw sequencing data of 16S rRNA gene amplicons generated from soil samples collected in an urban brownfield site following low-temperature desorption (LTTD) remediation. The samples were collected over a two-year period to track the recovery of soil chemistry and microbial communities after remediation treatment. The data include sequences from multiple time points, providing insights into changes in microbial diversity, community structure, and predicted functional profiles in response to the remediation process.

PRJEB90852.title: Seasonal changes in microbial community composition of Arctic sea-ice ridges
PRJEB90852.description: The yearlong MOSAiC ice drift (October 2019 to September 2020), with the research vessel Polarstern serving as the base, started in the eastern Eurasian Basin and crossed the Amundsen and Nansen basins towards the Fram Strait (Fig. 1) (e.g. Nicolaus et al., 2022; Fong et al., 2024). One dedicated research project (Ridges - Safe HAVens for ice-associated flora and fauna in a seasonally ice-covered Arctic Ocean (HAVOC) (Granskog and Müller, 2024) performed detailed and interdisciplinary observations of ridges during MOSAiC. During the drift, three different ridges were sampled at different times of the year. The changes between ridges were necessary, as logistical challenges and ice dynamics prevented the sampling of the same ridge throughout the entire period. The first ridge (R1) was investigated in winter, the second ridge (R2) was investigated in spring, and the third ridge (R3) was investigated in summer. Ice cores for temperature and salinity measurements as well as biogeochemical variables were extracted with a 9-cm (Mark II) internal diameter ice corer (Kovacs Enterprise, USA). Ice cores collected for biogeochemical variables were cut into 10 cm long sections in the field and collected in sterile plastic bags, with the focus on the three habitats: the ice of the roof and the floor of water-filled voids, the bottom of the ridge, and, when present, the frozen void and algae inclusions. Biogeochemical variables were, when possible, derived from pooled ice core sections of three replicate cores (R3), and during challenging weather periods (R1 and R2) from single ice cores. The core sections were kept dark and cool, transferred to the lab on board and melted in the dark after the addition of filtered seawater: 50 mL 0.22 µm filtered seawater was added per cm of sea ice thickness, and the sea ice samples melted within 24–36 hours in the dark at around 4°C. When possible, the water (20–30 L) inside the voids, below the ridge and below level ice, was sampled using a manual bilge pump with a silicon tube with a diameter of 20 mm into prewashed polyethylene containers. Both melted sea ice and water samples were filtered through a Sterivex 0.22 µm filter or, when volumes were < 500 mL (three sea ice samples), onto 0.22 µm Durapore filters. The filters were directly flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen, stored at -80°C, and at the end of the campaign, shipped to the University of Bergen on dry ice. DNA from Sterivex filters was extracted using the Qiagen PowerWater DNA kit, and the DNA from Durapore filters was extracted using the QIAGEN DNeasy Power Soil kit following the manufacturer’s instructions. The extracted DNA was stored at -20°C until PCR amplification and prepared for paired-end MiSeq sequencing (Illumina, CA, USA) using a two-step PCR method to amplify the V4 region of the eukaryotic 18S rRNA genes (EukA7F, Euk570R) and the V4 region of the bacterial and archaeal 16SrRNA genes (519F, 806RB) before attaching MiSeq adapter and barcode sequences. Comparative 18S rRNA gene data from first-year and second-year level ice (FYI and SYI) and surface seawater used in this study are part of the MOSAiC main programme, obtained from the Alfred-Wegener institute and can be found at ENA under the project number PRJNA895866.

PRJEB83593.title: Bacterial and archaeal 16S rRNA gene sequencing sediment samples at STA14, Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo
PRJEB83593.description: Short triplicate sediment cores were obtained from station 14, core STA14.01, STA14.03, STA14.04, in Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo, West Antarctic Peninsula in Austral summer 2019. The aim of this study was to identify and analyze the distribution and abundance of microbial populations in sediments influenced by enhanced glacial input of nutrients such as metal oxides. DNA was extracted from samples in a detailed depth profile. The bacterial and archaeal community composition was identified by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing. The study was funded by DFG Schwerpunktprogram SPP 1158.  Please contact the authors before using this data.

PRJEB72873.title: Bacterial and archaeal 16S rRNA gene sequencing sediment samples at STA01 Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo

The aim of this study was to identify and analyze the distribution and abundance of microbial populations in sediments influenced by enhanced glacial input of nutrients such as metal oxides. DNA was extracted from samples in a detailed depth profile. The bacterial and archaeal community composition was identified by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing. PRJNA1293735.title: Effects of PAHs enrichment on microbial community structure and function in the sediments of Antarctic and Arctic
PRJNA1293735.description: Understanding microbial community responses to polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) pollution is essential for assessing the current status of PAH contamination in polar regions. In this study, intertidal and marine sediments were enriched with a mixture of PAHs (naphthalene, phenanthrene, fluoranthene, pyrene, and anthracene). High throughput sequencing and functional prediction were combined to systematically analyze bacterial structural and functional responses to PAH exposure.

PRJNA1288782.title: Draft Genomes and Ethanol Production Capabilities of Two Cold-Adapted Mrakia Strains from the Arctic Region
PRJNA1288782.description: Mrakia is a yeast genus commonly found in cold environments such as the Antarctic and Arctic regions and is well known for its cold adaptation. Members of the Mrakia genus are capable of growing at subzero temperatures but typically do not grow at temperatures above 20 degrees. In this study, we isolated two cold-adapted yeast strains, Mrakia gelida PAMC 26583 and Mrakia robertii PAMC 26600, from Arctic lichens.

PRJEB91661.title: Seasonal microbial connectivity between ocean, cryosphere and atmosphere in Kongsfjorden
PRJEB91661.description: This dataset contains 16S and 18S rRNA amplicons from two sampling campaigns (autumn 2021 and spring 2022) in Kongsfjorden (Svalbard, 79°N). Here, we studied the microbial and glycobiological connectivity between the sea surface microlayer, the underlying seawater, snow, and aerosol particles.

PRJEB87654.title: Sequence type and strain level detection of Klebsiella pneumoniae in complex culture-based bacterial metagenomes: comparative study
PRJEB87654.description: Klebsiella pneumoniae is a major cause of human infections and is frequently associated with antimicrobial resistance (AMR). Carriage of K. pneumoniae in the gut is a major risk factor for infection and a reservoir for the spread of high-risk clonal lineages and associated AMR determinants. Accurate detection of K. pneumoniae at the subspecies level is therefore essential to better understand K. pneumoniae gut colonization ecology and clonal dissemination. This dataset consists of 52 K. pneumoniae culture-positive fecal microbiome samples from community-based adults selected from our previous culture-based K. pneumoniae carriage study  (Raffelsberger N, Gut Microbes, 2021) and is also associated with the comparison of culture-based detection of K. pneumoniae by qPCR and a whole metagenomic sequencing study by Lindstedt K, Gut Microbes, 2022. Sequencing libraries were prepared using TrueSeq Nano DNA Library Prep Kit and Swift Turbo 2S flex DNA Library Prep Kit. Samples were sequenced on the NovaSeq 6000 platform (Illumina) to a target depth of 20x106 pair-end reads at 150 bp.

PRJNA1284569.title: Permafrost thaw incubation of soils from three Alaskan sites
PRJNA1284569.description: The goal of this study was to understand how permafrost thaw impacts the microbiome and its contribution to carbon dioxide flux, using microcosm experiments with samples from three sites in Alaska. The sites are as follows: above the CRREL permafrost tunnel near Fairbanks, AK, the CRREL Farmer's Loop research site also near Fairbanks, AK , and the Barrow Experimental Observatory (BEO) in Utqiagvik, AK. We performed a 96-day thaw microcosm experiment at 2C with subsamples of permafrost. Data includes both in situ and post-thaw community compositions.

PRJEB91164.title: VIP-Seq of Shewanella psychrophila WP2
PRJEB91164.description: In order to identify and quantify prophages in supernatants of WP2 cultures with or without MMC, we performed the Virion Induction Profiling Sequencing (VIP-Seq).

PRJNA1281190.title: 16S and 18S rDNA Profiles of Glacier Sediment Microcosms
PRJNA1281190.description: Microcosms created using cryoconite sediment from the Canada glacier, Taylor Valley Antarctica were treated with Nitrogen and Phosphorus amendments to study how 16S and 18S rDNA based communities respond to the alleviation of different nutrient limitations.

PRJNA1279263.title: Integrating low-temperature anaerobic digestion with bioelectrochemical system for municipal wastewater: synergistic effects of promoting DIET-syntropy via magnetite and external applied voltage
PRJNA1279263.description: The perception of wastewater has shifted from a pollutant to a renewable resource, with anaerobic digestion (AD) emerging as a key technology for biogas production. However, AD performance at low temperatures is hindered by reduced microbial activity and biomass retention. To address these challenges, strategies such as magnetite-embedded granules (MEG) and advanced reactor designs have been explored to enhance microbial stability and electron transfer. Recently, integrating bioelectrochemical systems (BES) with AD, termed BEAD, has shown promise in improving methane yields and microbial activity under ambient conditions. This study investigates BEAD performance under low-temperature conditions using synthetic municipal wastewater, focusing on methane production, energy recovery, and microbial community dynamics.
PRJNA1279263.center_name: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology

PRJNA1277323.title: Vertebrates impact on bacterial community structure of coastal Arctic snowpacks in the spring
PRJNA1277323.description: A total of 39 surface snow samples were collected from four transects (Line A, B, C, D) closed to Polish Polar Station Hornsund (PPSH), Svalbard. Two transects (A, B) were established from the centre of a seabird little auk colony towards non-impacted areas along an altitudinal gradient, while two other parallel transects (C, D) were established closer to the coast.

PRJNA1276231.title: Comparative analysis of the structure and function of intestinal Bacteria in wild and captive Tundra swans
PRJNA1276231.description: Based on 16S rDNA high-throughput sequencing technology, this study conducted a comparative analysis of the composition and functional differences of the intestinal microbiota between wild and captive tundra swans. The research found that the intestinal microbiota of the two groups of tundra swans were highly consistent at the phylum level, and the Firmicutes and Proteobacteria were both highly abundant in both groups, indicating that host genetic factors play a decisive role in the composition of intestinal microbiota. However, differences in diet and environment have driven significant microbiota differentiation, and the wild population presents a unique oligodominant microbiota structure. Functional analysis revealed that the wild population significantly enriched the pathways of "cofactor and vitamin metabolism" and "porphyrin and chlorophyll metabolism". This study reveals the ecological mechanism by which tundra swans adapt to the environment through the interaction of "diet - microbiome - host", providing a scientific basis at the microbiome level for the protection and captive management of wild birds.

PRJNA1276466.title: Microbiome of Arctic hydrothermal plume
PRJNA1276466.description: This dataset comprises 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequences obtained from hydrothermal plume waters in the Arctic Ocean. Samples were collected during an oceanographic expedition targeting hydrothermally influenced water masses along the Mid-Arctic Ridge. Environmental DNA was extracted from filtered seawater samples, and the V3-V4 hypervariable regions of the 16S rRNA gene were amplified using universal primers. Sequencing was performed using the Illumina NextSeq2000 platform in 2x300 bp mode.
PRJNA1276466.center_name: Max Planck Institute for Marine Microbiology

PRJNA1275771.title: Bacterial communities in iron-rich alpine wetlands
PRJNA1275771.description: Understanding the ecological mechanisms underlying microbial community assembly in extreme environments is central to microbial ecology. However, the response patterns of bacterial communities in specific extreme habitats, such as iron-rich alpine wetlands, remain poorly characterized. This study collected sediment samples from four iron-rich wetlands located on the eastern margin of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
PRJNA1275771.center_name: Southwest University of Science and Technology

PRJNA1274944.title: Homo sapiens Metagenome
PRJNA1274944.description: For viral metagenomic analysis, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples were collected from 10 patients with encephalitis of unknown etiology in 2023. The 10 CSF samples were randomly pooled into a single specimen pool. This pooled sample was resuspended in 1 mL DPBS and subjected to three rapid freeze-thaw cycles on dry ice. After centrifugation (10 minutes, 15,000 g), the supernatant was collected and filtered through a 0.45 uL membrane (Millipore) to remove eukaryotic and bacterial cell-sized particles. From the filtered supernatant, 200 uL was treated with a nuclease cocktail to reduce free (non-viron-protected) nucleic acids. Total nucleic acids were extracted from the treated sample using the QIAamp MinElute Virus Spin Kit per the manufacturer's protocol. A single library was prepared with the Nextera XT DNA Sample Preparation Kit (Illumina) and sequenced on the MiSeq Illumina platform, generating 250 bases paired ends with dual barcoding for the pool.

PRJEB86671.title: Variation in Antarctic fur seals' skin and gut microbiota in relation to host-specific and environmental factors
PRJEB86671.description: Comparative studies of microbial communities occupying different body sites in wild vertebrates are scarce, but they are crucial for advancing our understanding of the ecological and evolutionary factors shaping animal microbiomes. We therefore used a “natural experiment” comprising mother-offspring pairs from two adjacent Antarctic fur seal breeding colonies that differ in social density to investigate differences between skin and gut microbial communities in relation to host-specific and environmental factors. Using 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing, we uncovered a strong influence of colony on the diversity and composition of skin but not gut microbial communities. Specifically, we observed a suppressive effect of high social density on skin microbial alpha diversity as well as an overabundance of phyla associated with diseases and bite wounds in the high-density colony. Our findings suggest that skin microbial communities may be more sensitive to external factors, whereas gut communities are more tightly regulated by the host. Overall, this study highlights the importance of considering multiple body sites and their distinct microbial communities to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the factors shaping microbial diversity and composition in marine mammals.
PRJEB86671.center_name: University of Bielefeld, Faculty of Biology

PRJNA1270919.title: Distinct Gut Bacterial Composition of Mesopelagic Fishes Inside and Outside the Cold Seep Environment
PRJNA1270919.description: Cold seeps, unique deep-sea ecosystems driven by hydrocarbon- and sulfide-rich fluid fluxes, support mesopelagic fish communities. Fish gut microbiota are vital to host metabolism and health, and interact closely with surrounding water environment. However, information on gut bacterial composition and potential functional profiles of mesopelagic fishes in the cold seep has rarely been explored. In this study, high-throughput sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene was used to compare gut microbiota of mesopelagic fishes collected in the cold seep environment and outside the cold seep environment . Significant differences were found in gut bacterial composition and predicted functional profiles between the two distinct fish habitats. The genera Blastopirellula, Ruegeria, and Rubripirellula, which are involved in sulfide and hydrocarbon transformations, were significantly more abundant in cold seep fish. In contrast, Acinetobacter was significantly enriched in fish outside the cold seep. The difference of gut bacterial composition between the two habitats were primarily driven by the abundan subcommunities. Co-occurrence network analysis revealed more complex gut microbiome networks in cold seep fishes, characterized by higher node degree and connectivity but lower modularity. Together, these findings demonstrate that the cold seep environment strongly shapes both the structure and metabolic potential of mesopelagic fish gut microbiota, and highlight gut microbial contributions to host adaptation in chemosynthesis-based habitats.
PRJNA1270919.center_name: South China Sea Fisheries Research Institute

PRJDB15542.title: Successional development of soil fungal community on a glacier foreland  in The High Arctic
PRJDB15542.description: This project aimed to investigate soil fungal communities' temporal and spatial succession on a well-vegetated glacier foreland on Ellesmere Island in the Canadian High Arctic. To assess the fungal succession trajectory, we established plots near the glacier terminus and on glacier moraines differing in time after deglaciation along the Arklio Glacier foreland ecosystem.

PRJNA1265943.title: Terrestrial fungal metagenome
PRJNA1265943.description: This study aims to evaluate the performance of commonly used bioinformatic pipelines in processing fungal metabarcoding data by comparing their outputs against a high-resolution taxonomic reference. Using a unique dataset from 56 plots, where terricolous lichenized fungi were surveyed both through traditional specimen-based identification and Sanger sequencing, and through environmental DNA metabarcoding, the study assesses how different pipelines influence biodiversity estimates. By doing so, it seeks to inform ecologists about the implications of bioinformatic choices and guide the selection of optimal data processing strategies for accurate and reliable biodiversity assessments in natural communities.

PRJNA1259695.title: Low temperature resistant organic pollutant degrading bacteria
PRJNA1259695.description: DBP, as a kind of substance widely used in PAEs, enters the natural environment in large quantities through human activities and affects the normal growth of crops, reducing crop yield. At the same time, DBP can enter the human body through the food chain, affecting the normal development and metabolic function of human beings, while the normal operation of the immune system, reproductive system and endocrine system will also be affected. In serious cases, it has three effects on human beings and future generations. Due to its stable chemical structure in the natural environment, the degradation efficiency of DBP by photocatalysis and microorganisms in nature is low. However, the agricultural development area in Northeast China is in a cold climate, and the daily light time is lower than that in other areas. The degradation efficiency of DBP by soil protozoa is very low, and the black soil has been polluted by DBP for a long time, which has greatly restricted the local agricultural development. Because the process of physical adsorption and chemical catalysis of DBP is cumbersome and inefficient, it is one of the most innovative and promising technologies to apply exogenous microorganisms to the soil for efficient, green and rapid degradation of DBP by microbial remediation

PRJNA1246243.description: NGS data for 202 soil samples taken across the Antarctic Wright Valley, from ice plateau to the coast. This project looks at soil microbial community changes across varying geomorphological features in the landscape alongside other soil and environmental properties.

PRJNA1237803.title: Environmental 16S samples associated with an investigation of Strongylocentrotus purpuratus larvae under different environmental conditions during early development
PRJNA1237803.description: This project contains 16S files used to analyze the seawater conditions in which larval Strongylocentrotus purpuratus were raised. Shaping of the epigenomic landscape by local environments during early life stages could initiate adaptive plasticity, allowing developing organisms to optimize their phenotypes for local conditions. Elevated seawater temperature, in addition to being an independent stressor, can alter marine microbial communities, leading to increased bacterial loads and pathogen spread, making it imperative to understand how plasticity in physiological and molecular traits of marine organisms are impacted, especially the immune system. We examined how early developmental exposure to elevated temperature and host-associated microbes influence larval morphology, immune cell development, and the epigenome of the purple sea urchin (Strongylocentrotus purpuratus). Embryos were reared in four conditions: ambient or elevated temperature (14C or 18C) and two levels of microbial content (low richness (sterilized artificial sea water; SASW) or high richness (microbiome-exposed; MBE)). Larvae raised in SASW or at 18C were larger and had more pigment cells (antimicrobial immune cells) at 5 days post fertilization than MBE larvae. Development in MBE led to increased chromatin accessibility, predominantly in promoter regions, whereas 18C altered very few chromatin regions but was associated with more differentially expressed genes. Both developmental temperature and microbial content regulate larval metabolism, transcription/translation, and chromatin organization at the gene expression level, but often in opposing directions. Finally, larvae raised in MBE or 18C exhibited delayed immune system development. Overall, we showed that early developmental environments strongly influence whole-organism and molecular phenotypes, with early exposure to microbes altering the host immune system and epigenome.

PRJNA1237878.title: Carnobacterium maltaromaticum strain:2857 Genome sequencing
PRJNA1237878.description: The psychrophilic strain Carnobacterium maltaromaticum 2857, isolated from Arctic postglacial deposits (Hans Glacier, Spitsbergen Is.), exhibits the ability to produce 1,2-propanediol from glycerol, a byproduct of biodiesel production.

PRJNA828511.title: Microbiome of the green seaweed Ulva (Chlorophyta)
PRJNA828511.description: The aim of this study is to investigate how the microbiome associated with the green seaweed Ulva (Chlorophyta) responds to various external stressors, including environmental fluctuations, anthropogenic pollution, and conditions related to aquaculture. By examining changes in microbial community composition and function, the research seeks to better understand the dynamic interactions between Ulva and its microbiota in a changing environment, with a specific focus on algal growth and morphogenesis factors (AGMPF) released by the core microbiome of Ulva.

PRJNA1236883.title: Effects of Environmental Temperature Variation on Gut Microbiota and Fecal Metabolome in Captive Yangtze finless porpoise (Neophocaena asiaeorientalis asiaeorientalis)
PRJNA1236883.description: The current research investigates the physiological responses of captive YFP to different temperatures by using 16S rRNA and UHPLC.

PRJNA1236362.title: Microbial Marvels of the Antarctic: Untangling Life in the Ice
PRJNA1236362.description: This project aims to explore the diverse microbial communities thriving in the extreme conditions of Antarctica. By examining various habitats, including glacial ice, permafrost, and cryoconite, we will investigate the adaptations and ecological roles of these microorganisms. Our research seeks to uncover the genetic, physiological, and functional characteristics of these microbial populations, shedding light on their contributions to nutrient cycling and ecosystem dynamics. Through advanced molecular techniques and environmental sampling, we aim to deepen our understanding of how life persists in one of Earth's harshest environments and the potential implications for climate change and biodiversity.

PRJNA1235229.title: Glacier-fed stream diatoms from the Rwenzori Mountains, Uganda
PRJNA1235229.description: Glacier-fed streams (GFSs) are harsh environments hosting unique, highly specialized communities. Interestingly, glaciers and their GFSs are also present in Earths tropical regions, where environmental characteristics contrast with GFS conditions elsewhere. Yet, despite the unique and isolated nature of tropical GFSs, little is known about their inhabitants, even though they may disappear later this century with ongoing climate change. Here, we examined diatom communities from one of the last tropical African GFSs in the Rwenzori Mountains, Uganda, to characterize the composition and diversity of this unique system. Six sediment-associated biofilm samples were collected from two reaches of a stream draining the Mt. Stanley Glacier, and the resident diatom communities were studied morphologically using light and scanning electron microscopy, as well as through the sequencing of amplicons from extracted DNA (18S and rbcL). In general, morphological results agree well with barcoding results, but each individually provides irreplaceable insights. In total, we identify 24 morphotypes utilizing light microscopy, 101 diatom Amplicon Sequence Variants (ASVs) using 18S sequences, and 65 ASVs with rbcL. Across approaches, common genera include Achnanthidium, Psammothidium, Neidium, Cymbopleura, Eunotia, and Pinnularia. However, only about half of the diversity could be assigned to the species level across methodologies, including several of the most common taxa, indicating a high level of uniqueness. Accordingly, one of the most common taxa encountered is described here as a new species, Neidium rwenzoriense sp. nov. Our results emphasize the Rwenzori Mountains as a global hotspot for endemism, and the novelty of disappearing tropical GFSs as diatom habitats.

PRJNA1140524.title: DIET-SAO Baltic-Consortia enriched from the Bothnian Bay methanogenic zone Rotarulab, Danijel Jovicic Metagenomic assembly
PRJNA1140524.description: Acetate is a key intermediate in mineralizing organic matter, especially in deep subsurface environments with limited electron acceptors. Here, methanogenic archaea can split acetate to CH4 and CO2, while acetate-oxidizing bacteria can oxidize it to CO2 providing reducing equivalents for methanogens.In sediment enrichments from Bothnian Bay, we investigated how conductive particles affect marine acetate metabolism. Granular-activated-carbon (GAC) and magnetite were crucial for linking syntrophic acetate oxidation (SAO) with CO2-reductive methanogenesis, known as CIET (Conductive Particle-mediated Interspecies Electron Transfer). Our previous observations showed a fourfold increase in methanogenesis with conductive particles compared to controls (no conductive particles). Labeled acetate was primarily taken up by a Geobacterales-like organism, converting the 13CH3-group to 13CO2. Inhibition experiments confirmed a metabolic co-dependency between Archaea and Bacteria, using Methyl-CoM inhibitors or antibiotics.Metagenomic analyses identified core CIET organisms exclusively present in incubations with conductive particles. Metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) from these particles included the main players: a Geobacterales and a Methanosarcina, found only in such incubations.The Methanosarcina, typical of marine environments, harbors an Rnf-operon flanked by a membrane-bound methanogenesis multiheme cytochrome capable of bidirectional Extracellular Electrons Transfer (EET). The Geobacterales-MAG showcases over 40 multiheme c-type cytochromes, acetate transporters, and a complete acetate-oxidation pathway, confirming their potential for acetate-oxidation, and EET-capabilities.While these two organisms are key in acetate oxidation, other groups in the consortia may have secondary functions. Our findings highlight complex microbial interactions and diverse strategies in CIET, providing valuable insights into the metabolic capabilities of marine sediment consortia related to methane emissions.This study presents, for the first time, a well-characterized environmental DIET consortium using conductive particles, which appears to employ new electron exchange transfer methods. This consortium depends on conductive particles to maintain and process syntrophic acetate oxidation.

PRJNA1219359.title: 16S_Diversity, function and activity of syntrophic propionate and butyrate bacteria in the proglacial lake sediment of Qiangyong glacier, the Tibetan Plateau
PRJNA1219359.description: Proglacial lake is an emergent source of the second most important greenhouse gas methane as the climate continues to warm, and syntrophic bacteria play a crucial role in the sediment organic matter degradation and methane production. However, our understanding of syntrophic bacteria in the proglacial lake sediments is largely unknown. By applying 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing, metagenomic and metatranscriptomic sequencing on samples from non-ablation seasons, we analyzed the diversity, function, and activity of syntrophic propionate- and butyrate-oxidizing bacteria (SPOB and SBOB) in the sediments of a typical proglacial lake fed by Qiangyong glacier on the south Tibetan Plateau. We found a diverse array of putative canonical syntrophic bacteria, which exhibited an obvious spatial and temporal heterogeneity and played key roles in the species interaction network.

PRJNA1229836.title: Nodaviridae sp. Genome sequencing
PRJNA1229836.description: For viral metagenomic analysis, cerebrospinal fluid specimens were collected from patients with encephalitis of unknown etiology in China. The CSF samples were pooled into one specimen pool and thoroughly mixed, resuspended in 1 mL of DPBS, and subjected to three rapid freeze-thaw cycles on dry ice. The supernatants were collected after centrifugation (10 minutes, 15,000 g) and filtered through a 0.45 um filter (Millipore) to remove eukaryotic and bacterial cell-sized particles. A 200 uL aliquot of the supernatant from the pool was treated with a nuclease enzyme mixture to reduce the concentration of free (non-viral encapsidated) nucleic acids. The remaining total nucleic acids were isolated using the QIAamp MinElute Virus Spin Kit according to the manufacturer's protocol. One library was constructed using the Nextera XT DNA Sample Preparation Kit (Illumina) and sequenced on the Illumina NovaSeq platform with a 150 bp paired-end sequencing strategy.

PRJNA1230869.title: Effects of low-temperature alkali urine pretreatment on microbial diversity during continuous anaerobic fermentation of maize straw during methane production
PRJNA1230869.description: The effects of alkali urine pretreatment on anaerobic microbial diversity were determined by analyzing the microbial changes after fermentation at 6% and 10% feed concentrations under the condition of 7%/12% NaOH/urea solid-liquid ratio of 1:1

PRJNA1230284.title: Heterogeneity of the horizontal environment drives community assemblages and species coexistence of prokaryotic communities in cold seep sediments
PRJNA1230284.description: 1. Habitat heterogeneity affected the species coexistence and community assembly.2. CH4 was the key driving factor of prokaryotic community diversity and assembly.3. The assembly of prokaryotic communities were mainly stochastic processes.4. Bacteria and archaea showed different coexistence patterns in seepage area.

PRJNA1227537.title: Carbon monoxide oxidation by anaerobic methanotrophic consortia
PRJNA1227537.description: Anaerobic methanotrophic consortia, primarily constituting methane-oxidizing archaea (ANME) and sulfate-reducing bacteria (SRB), were a well-known example of importance in methane cycling and climate change. Besides methane, however, few studies have investigated the utilization of other electron donors for the consortia, of which carbon monoxide (CO) is predicted to be a potential electron source due to its low reduction potential and presence in the environment. Here this study explored the prediction for CO metabolism by ANME-SRB using microcosm experiments coupled with geochemical measurements and single-cell activity detection. CO metabolism across anaerobic methanotrophic consortia, which can be an important shunt for the methane cycling in the methane seep sediments. The versatile capability of CO oxidation by anaerobic methanotrophic consortia broadens the dimension of carbon cycling in the methane seeps and highlights the importance of microbes in the climate change.

PRJNA1227241.title: Investigating DNA methylation in sea-ice Bacteria
PRJNA1227241.description: This study aimed to identify whether bacterial sea-ice communities use DNA methylation, and if so, in what way. We sampled sea-ice brines from an Arctic ice-floe in May 2023, using a stepped sackhole brine methods. Samples of sackhole brines were obtained from the top, middle, and bottom of the ice. Brine was filtered onto a 0.2 micron filter at cold temperature, and then flash frozen. The filters were extracted and sequenced using Nanopore. Metagenome assembled genomes were curated after assembly, and reads mapped back onto each MAG to obtain methylation information. We identified methylation motifs then conducted a comparative analysis of each motif's methylation levels across the ice horizons. In tandem with methylation related gene identification and functional annotations, this allows us to assign (or not) a regulatory role to DNA methylation. Motif identification in viral contigs allows us to hypothesize about possible host-phage relationships.

PRJNA1226912.title: A strain of low temperature and high salt tolerant nitrogen removing bacteria was isolated from domestic sewage in Inner Mongolia. This Pseudomonas knackmussii L4 can effectively metabolize ammonia nitrogen, nitrate nitrogen, and nitrite nitrogen.
PRJNA1226912.description: In this experiment, a heterotrophic nitrification-aerobic denitrification (HN-AD) strain with low-temperature tolerance and high-salt tolerance was screened from the activated sludge in the aerobic section of a domestic sewage treatment plant in Inner Mongolia. Through morphological characteristics and 16S rDNA analysis, it was identified and named as Pseudomonas knackmussii L4.

PRJEB83087.title: Alaska methane cycling microbiome
PRJEB83087.description: The methane-cycling microbiomes in Arctic permafrost-affected upland soils play crucial roles in the production and consumption of this important greenhouse gas. However, little is known about the distributions of Arctic methanogens and methanotrophs across the regional scale and along the vertical soil profile, as well as their responses to the widespread permafrost thaw. Using a unique sample set from nine different locations across the pan-Arctic, we identified methanogen and methanotroph phylotypes in 729 datasets of 16S rRNA gene amplicons.  In 621 samples of intact permafrost soils across the pan-Arctic, only 22 methanogen and 26 methanotroph phylotypes were identified. Abundances of both functional groups varied significantly between sites and soil horizons. Only four methanogen phylotypes were detected at all locations, with the hydrogenotrophic Methanobacterium lacus dominating. Remarkably, the permafrost soil methane filter was almost exclusively comprised of a few phylotypes closely related to the obligate methanotrophic species Methylobacter tundripaludum.  In degraded permafrost sites in Alaska, M. tundripaludum also dominated the methanotroph microbiome in the wet site. However, in dry, water-drained former permafrost site, Methylocapsa phylotypes, closely related with the atmospheric methane oxidizing bacteria, were exclusively found and dominant, indicating a massive restructuring of the methanotroph guild that consequently resulted in functional changes from a soil methane filter to an atmospheric methane sink.   This study provides first insights into the identity and intricate spatial distribution of methanotrophs and methanogens in permafrost soils at a pan-Arctic scale and their responses to different water status after permafrost degradation. These findings point towards a few key microbes particularly relevant for future studies on Arctic CH4 dynamics in a warming climate and that under future dry conditions more atmospheric CH4 uptake in Arctic upland soils might happen.

PRJNA1165500.title: AIRBORNE BACTERIAL COMMUNITY ON ANTARCTIC PENINSULA
PRJNA1165500.description: This study explores the geographical influence at different scales on the composition of airborne microbial community in the Antarctic Peninsula region. Air sampling was conducted during the austral summer in Byers Peninsula (Livingston Island, South Shetland Islands) and Avian Island (Marguerite Bay) 672 km apart.

PRJNA1215356.description: This work intended to highlight the bacterial communities present in several glaciers from Norway, Svalbard and Peru.

PRJNA1214840.title: Antarctica Survey Soil Sequencing
PRJNA1214840.description: This sequencing data was generated to help describe the relationships between microbial diversity and ecosystem functioning across a collection of Antarctic soils from previously archived collections. Our study aims to describe the taxonomic diversity of the dominant microbial communities in these unique soil environments, and to make predictions about patterns of community assembly and function.

PRJNA1212501.title: Bacterial metagenome from Svalbard fjords, Arctic
PRJNA1212501.description: Analyzing bacterial diversity from the Svalbard fjords through 16S v3-v4 Amplicon sequencing. Manganese (Mn) enrichment experiment to understand the impact on bacterial diversity. Culture-based whole genome sequencing to understand the Mn oxidation genes in the isolated Mn oxidizing bacterial cultures.
PRJNA1212501.center_name: National centre for Polar and Ocean Research

PRJNA1211808.title: The microbial community of a melting Rocky Mountain glacier
PRJNA1211808.description: Glaciers in the Rocky Mountains of North America are disappearing rapidly, and with their disappearance, we may be losing as-yet-unstudied biodiversity and genetic resources. A variety of different habitats for microorganisms exist on these glaciers, especially within pockets of supraglacial sediments that support higher microbial abundances compared to bare ice. Here we characterize the microbial communities in contrasting sediment habitats on the surface of the Dinwoody Glacier in the Wind River Range of central Wyoming. We used biogeochemical approaches, high-throughput DNA sequencing, and microscopic observations to describe the biogeochemistry and the bacterial and eukaryotic communities of supraglacial sediments from 30 samples on Dinwoody Glacier.

PRJNA1211653.title: Taxonomically different symbiotic communities of sympatric Arctic sponge species show functional similarity with specialization at species level
PRJNA1211653.description: In this study, bacterial communities associated with three species of cold-water marine sponges (Isodictya palmata, Halichondria panicea, and Halichondria sitiens) and surrounding seawater from the White and Barents Seas were studied by 16S and shot-gun metagenomics.
PRJNA1211653.center_name: Skolkovo Institute of Science and Technology

PRJNA1207588.title: Endolithic microbial communities inside sediment-hosted carbonate nodules within and below the sulfate-methane transition zone
PRJNA1207588.description: Porous, authigenic carbonate concretions (nodules) precipitate in marine sediments as a result of anaerobic oxidation of methane (AOM) and are observed in marine methane seep sites around the world. These incipient rocks can also host active endolithic communities capable of performing AOM. The sequences in this study integrate the biological profiles of seep sediments within and below the SMTZ with the biological profiles of their seep carbonate nodules. By characterizing and quantifying similarities between nodules and host sediments, we explore shared formation histories and evidence for continued exchange after formation. Furthermore, depth-dependent transitions in community identity provide insights into the in situ geochemical conditions and anticipated niche adaptations where these endolithic communities occur. Together, these data expand our understanding of the endolithic communities in seep sediment-hosted carbonate nodules and how they may be shaped by past and present conditions.

PRJNA1206728.title: Auxiliary metagenomes
PRJNA1206728.description: Some auxiliary metagenomes of other environments were collected for investigating the dissemination of novel ARGs in polar soils.

PRJEB59507.title: Actinobacteria from Artic and Atlantic deep-sea sediments – biodiversity and Bacterial and bioactive potential
PRJEB59507.description: In this study we characterized the actinobacterial communities of the upper layers of deep-sea sediments from two oceans: the Artic and the Atlantic (Azores and Madeira) employing 16S rDNA metabarcoding analysis, and studied the diversity and the biosynthetic potential of cultivable actinobacteria retrieved from those samples.
PRJEB59507.center_name: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

PRJEB83594.title: Bacteria active during sulfate-reducing incubations with Potter Cove sediment
PRJEB83594.description: An RNA-stable isotope probing incubation experiment was performed, investigating the actively acetate assimilating or carbon fixating bacterial community under sulfate-reducing conditions with hydrogen or acetate as electron donors in Antarctic, glacial influenced sediments. Slurry was prepared in a 1:6 ratio of sediment and artificial sea water, amended with 28 mM sulfate and 0.5 mM dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC). The used sediment originated from pooled cores STA14.03 and STA14.04, 0-10 cm, at station 14 in Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo, West Antarctic Peninsula, retrieved in Austral summer 2019. The incubation experiment was performed anoxically for six treatments with 13C-labeled acetate or DIC and unlabeled controls in biological triplicates: (I) acetate + hydrogen, (II) acetate, (III) hydrogen, (IV) hydrogen + molybdate, (V) acetate + molybdate, (VI) nothing added. Incubation at 2 degrees C in the dark for 19 days.  RNA was extracted from pooled biological triplicates (except treatment III which was kept separate) and density separated by ultra-centrifugation. In selected retrieved fractions, the bacterial community was identified by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing on RNA (cDNA) level.  The study was funded by DFG Schwerpunktprogram SPP 1158.  Please contact the authors before using this data.

PRJEB83592.title: Bacterial 16S rRNA sequencing sediment samples at STA14, Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo
PRJEB83592.description: Short sediment core was obtained from station 14, core STA14.04, in Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo, West Antarctic Peninsula in Austral summer 2019. The aim of this study was to identify and analyze the distribution and abundance of microbial populations in sediments influenced by enhanced glacial input of nutrients such as metal oxides. RNA was extracted from samples in a depth profile.  The bacterial community composition was identified by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing on RNA (cDNA) level. The study was funded by DFG Schwerpunktprogram SPP 1158.  Please contact the authors before using this data.

PRJNA1200116.title: Small and mRNA sequencing of C> elegans fed different bacterial diets and grown at different temperatures
PRJNA1200116.description: The goal is to compare small and mRNA sequences from C. elegans grown in different environments. Worms were kept on either the E. coli species HT115 or HB101 for at least ten generations at 20C or 25C prior to sample collection.

PRJNA1196099.title: Distinct Microbial Communities Within and On Seep Carbonates Support Long-term Anaerobic Oxidation of Methane and Divergent pMMO Diversity
PRJNA1196099.description: Methane-seep carbonates, precipitated by anaerobic methane-oxidizing archaea and sulfate-reducing bacteria (ANME-SRB), can harbor active ANME-SRB communities within their interior, acting as methane sink and carbon storage. Carbonates with low methane oxidation activity can reactivate when methane resurges, suggesting carbonates serve as potential long-term methane sinks. Surface communities vary from diverse assemblages to sulfide-oxidizer dominance, or ANME-SRB biofilms, and contain diverse particulate methane monooxygenases, enzymes catalyzing methane, alkane, or ammonia oxidation.

PRJNA1180285.description: Strain Streptomyces sp. Da 82-17 was isolated from the rhizosphere of the Antarctic hair grass (Galindez Island, Maritime Antarctica). Studies of this strain have shown that it has a high growth-stimulating potential and can synthesize siderophores that bind Fe, Ni, Zn, Mn, and Cu and solubilize insoluble forms of phosphorus and zinc.
PRJNA1180285.center_name: Ivan Franko National University of Lviv

PRJEB72670.title: Disko methane-cycling microbiome
PRJEB72670.description: The methane-cycling microbiomes in Arctic permafrost-affected upland soils play crucial roles in the production and consumption of this important greenhouse gas. However, little is known about the distributions of Arctic methanogens and methanotrophs across the regional scale and along the vertical soil profile, respectively. Using a unique sample set from eight different locations across the pan-Arctic we screened for methanogen and methanotroph phylotypes in 621 datasets of 16S rRNA gene amplicons. Only 22 methanogen and 26 methanotroph phylotypes were identified in 621 upland soil samples. Relative abundances of both groups varied significantly between sites and soil horizons. Water content was not correlated with methanotroph abundance, but both were positively correlated with methanogen abundance. This suggested that water content might control methanogen abundance, which in turn drove methanotroph abundance by providing the substrate. Only four methanogen phylotypes were detected at all locations, with the hydrogenotrophic Methanobacterium lacus dominating. Remarkably, the methane filter was almost exclusively comprised of a few phylotypes closely related to the obligate methanotrophic bacterium Methylobacter tundripaludum SV96. This study provides first insights into the identity and intricate spatial distribution of methanotrophs and methanogens in permafrost soils at a pan-Arctic scale, and points towards a few key microbes particularly relevant for future studies due to permafrost thaw.

PRJNA1187830.title: Contrasting stability of fungal and bacterial communities during long-term decomposition of fungal necromass in Arctic tundra
PRJNA1187830.description: Decomposition is a crucial process in terrestrial ecosystems, driving nutrient cycling and carbon storage dynamics. Considering the amount of fungal necromass produced in soils annually, its decomposition represents an important nutrient recycling process. Understanding the decomposition dynamics and associated microbial communities of fungal necromass is essential for elucidating ecosystem functioning, especially in environmentally sensitive regions such as the Arctic tundra, which remain under-explored. In a three-year field experiment conducted in the Svalbard archipelago, we investigated the decomposition of two types of fungal necromass with differing biochemical properties. We studied the decomposition rate, changes in chemical composition, and the succession of fungal and bacterial communities associated with the decaying fungal necromass.
PRJNA1187830.center_name: Institute of Microbiology of the Czech Academy of Sciences

PRJNA950396.title: Low coverage sequencing across Phyllotis mice and a new reference genome.
PRJNA950396.description: Phyllotis vaccarum (previously Phyllotis xanthopygus rupestris) set the world record for the highest dwelling mammal in the world following the live capture of an animal at 6,739 m on the peak of Volcan Llullaillaco in Chile. Here we generated a quality reference genome for Phyllotis vaccarum as well as population level low coverage whole genome sequencing across the range of Phyllotis vaccarum and other species of Phyllotis. These data provide the opportunity to address questions relating to species limits and boundaries in the genus as well as genomic regions possibly under selection to extreme elevation.

PRJEB82428.title: Acetate degrading bacteria across temperature in Potter Cove sediment
PRJEB82428.description: An RNA-stable isotope probing incubation experiment was performed, investigating the actively acetate degrading bacterial community across a temperature gradient in Antarctic, glacial influenced sediments. Slurry was prepared in a 1:6 ratio of sediment and sulfate-free artificial sea water. The used sediment originated from core STA13.04, 0-29 cm, at station 13 in Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo, West Antarctic Peninsula, retrieved in Austral summer 2019. The incubation experiment was performed anoxically for three treatments with 13C-labeled acetate and according unlabeled controls: lepidocrocite (iron(III) oxide) + acetate, sulfate + acetate and acetate-only; in biological triplicates, incubated at 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25 or 30 degrees C in the dark. RNA was extracted from pooled biological triplicates and density separated by ultra-centrifugation. In selected retrieved fractions, the bacterial community was identified by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing on RNA (cDNA) level.  The study was funded by DFG Schwerpunktprogram SPP 1158.

PRJNA1178605.title: Metabarcoding of soil samples collected from King George Island during Scientific Antarctic Expedition ECA58
PRJNA1178605.description: Soil samples from three sites (Permafrost, Moraine, Deschampsia antarctica Rhizosphere) were collected on King George Island, near Ecology Glacier and the Henryk Arctowski Polish Antarctic Station, during the 58th Scientific Antarctic Expedition (ECA58). The microbial diversity of the samples was analyzed through metabarcoding targeting Bacteria, Archaea, and Fungi.

PRJEB74701.title: 16s rRNA dataset
PRJEB74701.description: The trace element iron (Fe) is a major constraint for microbially-mediated processes in the Southern Ocean. The accelerated melting of glaciers could present a novel source of Fe, but whether glacial Fe is bioavailable to marine microbes is not known. We investigated the response of marine heterotrophic prokaryotes to Fe contained in colloids (20 nm – 200 nm) of glacial origin collected on Kerguelen Island (Southern Ocean). We followed prokaryotic growth in incubation experiments amended either with colloids of glacial or non-glacial origin and determined community composition and the abundance of genes involved in Fe-related processes in metagenomes and MAGs at the final time point. Glacial colloids stimulated the growth of prokaryotic taxa belonging to Pseudomonadaceae and Vibrionaceae, while Rhodobacteraceae, Flavobacteriaceae and Alteromonadaceae were the dominant contributors to the communities in the incubations amended with non-glacial colloids. Metagenomic analysis revealed a higher abundance of genes involved in the biosynthesis of the siderophores pyoverdine and vibrioferrin as well as their respective transporters in the presence of glacial colloids as compared to the non-glacial colloids. Genes for the transport of both siderophores were present in diverse MAGs, while biosynthesis genes were detected in fewer ones. MAGs belonging to Nitrincolaceae and Pseudomonadaceae had among the highest gene counts for the synthesis and transport of both siderophores. Our results suggest that the utilization of siderophores facilitates the access to Fe from glacial colloids and point to the key role of specific prokaryotes rendering this source of Fe available to Southern Ocean microbial communities.
PRJEB74701.center_name: Bioavailability of iron from glacial matter

PRJNA1176684.description: metagenome reads from the Southern Ocean
