PRJNA1172671.title: Distinct bacterial community structures with abundant sulfur metabolism prevalently found among different sea ice types in the Central Arctic Ocean
PRJNA1172671.description: The rapid decline of sea ice in the relatively understudied Central Arctic Ocean has a significant impact on bacterial biodiversity and the ecological functions they support. We investigated the bacterial community composition and their associated metabolic functions from three geographically distinct sea ice floes at the North Pole, western Amundsen, and western Nansen basin. We resolved the bacterial community diversity inhabiting the sea ice habitat with species-level precision using a long-read amplicon sequencing approach. The study revealed 10 unique bacterial phyla, comprising 114 genera and 62 species, mainly belonging to Bacteroidota, Proteobacteria, and Cyanobacteria, which were found to be prevalent across the three ice stations. We relate community diversity to different physicochemical properties of sea ice, including ice age and ice floe origin, through sea ice back-trajectory analysis. We inferred key microbially mediated metabolic functions associated with carbon, sulfur, and nitrogen cycling processes among the three sites through genome-resolved metagenomics. The data suggests the prevalence of sulfur cycling-associated processes (assimilatory & dissimilatory sulfur metabolism) in the sea ice habitat. The heterotrophic bacterial groups were found to be dominant and significantly contribute to nutrient recycling and complex organic matter degradation during the summer sea ice melt season. Overall, our findings revealed that distinct differences were observed in bacterial community diversity and associated ecological functions correlating with sea ice type, origin and habitat characteristics in the Central Arctic Ocean.
PRJNA1172671.center_name: National Centre for Polar and Ocean Research

PRJNA1171893.title: Qilian Mountains permafrost soil eukaryotic microbiome (18S rRNA) Raw sequence reads
PRJNA1171893.description: Analyzing the microbial community structure in the permafrost soils of the Qilian Mountains under varying active layer thickness conditions.
PRJNA1171893.center_name: China Institute of Water Resources and Hydropower Research

PRJEB81236.title: Effects of simulated low-temperature thermal remediation on the microbial community of a tropical creosote contaminated soil
PRJEB81236.description: In the search for more sustainable remediation strategies for PAH-contaminated soils, an integrated application of thermal remediation and bioremediation (TEB) may allow the use of less impacting temperatures by associating heating to biological degradation. However, the influence of heating on soil microbiota remains poorly understood, especially in soils from tropical regions. This work investigated the effects of low-temperature heating on creosote-contaminated soil bacteria. We used culture- dependent and 16S rRNA sequencing methods to compare the microbial community of soil samples heated to 60 and 100 oC for 1 h in microcosms. Heating to 60 °C reduced the density of cultivable heterotrophic bacteria compared to control soil (p < 0.05), and exposure to 100 °C inactivated the viable heterotrophic community. Burkholderia-Caballeronia-Paraburkholderia (BCP) and Sphingobium were the predominant genera. Temperature and incubation time affected the Bray-Curtis dissimilarity index (p < 0.05). At 60 °C and 30 days incubation, the relative abundance of Sphingobium decreased and BCP increased dominance. There heated network after 30 days showed less nodes and edges, however maintained its density and complexity. Both main genera are associated with PAH degradation, indicating a possible functional redundancy and is likely to maintain biodegradation ability at higher temperatures. We concluded that TEB may be a feasible strategy, allowing biodegradation in temperature ranges where thermal remediation does not completely remove contaminants.

PRJNA1171782.title: Qilian Mountains permafrost soil microbiome Raw sequence reads

PRJNA1171096.title: Methane-powered sea spiders: Diverse, epibiotic methanotrophs serve as a novel source of nutrition for deep-sea methane seep Sericosura
PRJNA1171096.description: Sericosura sea spiders (family Pycnogonidae) from a methane seep along the southern California margin appear to host a methylotrophic bacterial community on their exoskeleton as an alternative food source. Sea spider-associated bacterial families included the Methylomonadaceae, Methylophagaceae (both gammaproteobacteria), and the Methylophilaceae (betaproteobacteria).

PRJNA1168701.title: Regulation and mechanism of intestinal microbes on low-temperature adaptive evolution of Pomacea canaliculate
PRJNA1168701.description: In order to analyze the role and mechanism of intestinal microbes in regulating the low-temperature adaptive evolution of Pomacea canaliculate, metagenomic and metabolomic analyses were carried out in the tropical and temperate populations of Pomacea canaliculate. The metagenomic results showed that the structure and composition of the intestinal microbial community in Pomacea canaliculate changed significantly. The results of metabolome showed that the characteristics of intestinal Microbial metabolism in Pomacea canaliculate were significantly different in different temperature zones. Compared with the tropical group, the intestinal microbial energy metabolism and protein synthesis in the temperate group were significantly increased. The results showed that in order to adapt to low temperature stress, the intestinal microflora of Pomacea canaliculate had significant adaptation changes in community structure and metabolic function.

PRJNA1170261.title: Mariprofundus ferrooxydans PV-1 Genome and Transposon Mutagenesis Sequencing
PRJNA1170261.description: Deep sequencing analysis of a transposon mutagenesis experiment performed on the Fe(II)-oxidizing Zetaproteobacterium Mariprofundus ferrooxydans PV1. Additionally, the genome of M. ferrooxydans PV-1 was completed to allow for complete analysis of the mutagenesis experiment.

PRJNA1166114.title: Gut microbiota in rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss with different susceptibility to Flavobacterium psychrophilum infection
PRJNA1166114.description: Two genetic lineages of rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss, with relatively high (HR) and low (LR) resistance towards the bacterial pathogen Flavobacterium psychrophilum, respectively, were produced based on Chr25 QTL marker assisted selection. A controlled bath challenge with F. psychrophilum in a common garden set-up confirmed the differential resistance status of the fish strains. Analysis of surviving fish thirty days post-challenge showed that the expression of immune related genes in the intestinal wall of the fish differed significantly between high resistant HR and LR fish. A range of genes encoding cytokines (IL-1, Il-2, IL-4/13, IL-6, IL-10, IL-17, IL-22), innate immune effector molecules (SAA, cathelicidins, complement, hepcidin) and the immunoglobulin IgD gene were significantly upregulated in the HR fish, whereas corresponding genes (except of the SAA gene) remained unregulated in LR fish. We analyzed the gut content from fish in all groups in order to elucidate to what extent the gut microbiota could be influenced by host genes and pathogen exposure. The alpha diversity analysis, also for subgroups, supported our finding that the differences in alpha diversity could be only observed in the control group but not in the infected group. The differences between gut microbiotas in the two fish strains decreased after exposure. The study suggests a continuous cross-talk between host genetics, innate immune responses in the host intestinal wall and the microbial community of the fish gut.

PRJNA1165965.title: Cryoconite bacterial community in Tibetan plateau
PRJNA1165965.description: Four glaciers in different regions of the Tibetan Plateau were chosen in the present study. Samples of the cryoconite sediments (C) and overlying water (W) of cryoconite holes and surface cryoconite (SC) were collected from four glaciers during July and September 2019.

PRJNA1164006.title: Raw sequence reads of LXZ glacier
PRJNA1164006.description: In this study, we collected snow, ice, and cryoconite samples from the Longxiazai Glacier on the Tibetan Plateau. By employing amplicon and metagenomic sequencing techniques, we compared the species and functional characteristics of diverse habitats.

PRJNA1163427.title: Janthinobacterium sp. CG_23.3 Genome sequencing
PRJNA1163427.description: Genome sequencing to study supraglacial carbon cycling

PRJNA1164985.title: Archaea exhibit different geographical distribution patterns compared to bacteria and fungi in Arctic marine sediments
PRJNA1164985.description: Microbial geographical distribution in the arctic marine sediments

PRJNA1081793.title: glacial ecosystem Raw sequence reads
PRJNA1081793.description: We investigated the microbial communities of seven habitats in three glacial ecosystems (i.e. snow, cryoconite and stream in supraglacial ecosystem; meltwater and sediment in subglacial ecosystem; lake water and sediment in proglacial ecosystem), and analyzed the contribution of supra- and sub-glacial ecosystems to pro-glacial ecosystem in the Tibetan Plateau by using 16S rRNA gene sequencing.

PRJNA1164146.title: Biogenic Ice Nucleating Particles and Bioaerosols in Arctic Marine Environments
PRJNA1164146.description: Atmospheric ice nucleating particles (INPs) play a critical role in cloud formation, influencing both radiative and physical properties. Biogenic INPs are particularly effective in catalyzing ice formation, triggering heterogeneous freezing between -1 degrees Celsius and -15 degrees Celsius, which can impact mixed-phased clouds by enhancing precipitation and reducing albedo. Arctic waters are known to harbour highly active INPs, and the ongoing reduction of sea ice extent and the increasing exposure to open ocean may lead to elevated aerosolization rates of marine bioaerosols and INPs. In this study, we investigated INPs and microbial cells from ambient marine air and laboratory sea spray experiments, as well as from sea bulk water (SBW) and sea surface microlayer (SML) samples collected along a latitudinal transect from the Davis Strait to Baffin Bay, off the west coast of Greenland. We observed an increase in INP concentrations in SBW with increasing latitude, independent of terrestrial freshwater input. A positive correlation was found between INP concentrations in the SBW and the absolute abundance of specific bacterial and eukaryotic taxa, such as Lewinella and Dino-Group-I-Clade-5, suggesting these taxa may have ice-nucleation activity potential. We observed a clear distinction between the seawater microbiome and the above airborne microbiome. This indicates contributions from terrestrial sources through long-range transport to the collected ambient marine air samples. However, INP concentrations were elevated at higher latitudes in both air samples and sea spray experiments, correlating with INP levels in the SBW. INP concentrations in sea spray were significantly elevated compared to air samples, indicating that marine INP aerosolization is influenced by environmental factors, such as wind speed. Additionally, the taxa identified to correlate with INP concentrations in SBW showed no preference for aerosolization, suggesting a stochastic aerosolization process, as demonstrated in our sea spray experiments. This study enhances our understanding of the aerosolization process and underscores the contribution of Arctic marine-derived biogenic INPs to the atmosphere, highlighting the role of the Arctic Oceans as a major source of atmospheric biogenic INPs.

PRJNA1160036.title: fungal ITS sequencing of Larix larix forest soil of the Greater Khingan Range during freeze-thaw period
PRJNA1160036.description: The project is to conduct microbial sequencing of soil samples of Larix larix forest of the Greater Khingan Range during freeze-thaw period, including ITS sequence of soil fungi.
PRJNA1160036.center_name: Institute of Natural Resources And Ecology

PRJEB63480.title: Rhizosphere microbiome in the Hallstätter glacier forefield using amplicon sequencing
PRJEB63480.description: Rhizosphere microbiome assembly is essential for plant resilience and health, but the temporal dimension of this process remains mostly unexplored. We used a chronosequence of 150 years in the foreland of the retreating Hallstätter glacier (Dachstein, Austria) to disentangle this exemplarily for the rhizosphere of three alpine plant species (Papaver alpinum L., Hornungia alpina (L.) O. Appel, and Sedum atratum L.).
PRJEB63480.center_name: INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL BIOTECHNOLOGY, GRAZ UNIVERSITY OF TECHNOLOGY

O. Appel, and Sedum atratum L.).

PRJNA1126331.description: Metagenomics and single-cell genomics analysis of Antarctic geothermal habitats

PRJEB75958.title: REpeated Fecal microbiota REStoration in Hiv
PRJEB75958.description: Changes in the microbiota have been linked to persistent inflammation during treated HIV infection. In this pilot double-blind study, we study 30 HIV-infected subjects on antiretroviral therapy (ART) with a CD4/CD8 ratio < 1 randomized to either weekly fecal microbiota capsules or placebo for 8 weeks. Stool donors were rationally selected based on their microbiota signatures. We report that fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is safe, not related to severe adverse events, and attenuates HIV-associated dysbiosis. FMT elicits changes in gut microbiota structure, including significant increases in alpha diversity, and a mild and transient engraftment of donor’s microbiota during the treatment period. FMT also modulates systemic inflammation. Gut microbiota manipulation using a non-invasive and safe strategy of FMT delivery is feasible and deserves further investigation. Trial number: NCT03008941.
PRJEB75958.center_name: Instituto Ramon y Cajal de Investigacion Sanitaria

PRJNA1152638.title: Changes in Permafrost Bacterial Community Composition after Thaw Across Multiple Alaskan Locations
PRJNA1152638.description: This laboratory study investigated how microbiome communities from six Alaskan permafrost samples, collected from various locations, shift under a uniform thaw regime. We assessed permafrost communities before and at the end of an 8-week incubation period, during which we applied stepwise increases in temperature. The study aimed to evaluate variability in microbial communities within intact permafrost and understand community assembly processes. Our results align with previous research, highlighting the variability in both abiotic properties and microbial community composition across different permafrost sites.

PRJNA1146409.title: 16S rRNA from McMurdo Dry Valley Lakes
PRJNA1146409.description: 16S rRNA sequence libraries were generated at various depths along a transect from Lake Fryxell, in the McMurdo Dry Valleys, Antarctica.

PRJNA1141887.title: Whole Genome of an Antarctic Psychrobacter
PRJNA1141887.description: To study the presence and novelty of antimicrobial genes in Antarctic bacteria

PRJNA1146794.title: Various sparse Proteobacteria assemblages in the deep, close-to-bedrock Elbrus glacier could indicate local climate changes as well as volcanic activity in the past
PRJNA1146794.description: The study's objective was to search for microbial communities in the deepest layers of the Elbrus glacier, close to the bedrock. The study aimed to test the hypothesis that microbial assemblages deposited in high mountain environments could provide information about past local climate variations. The ice coring was carried out on the Western plateau of Mt Elbrus, 5115m above sea level) glacier in the Caucasus, Russia (2009). The deepest ice sample (closest to bedrock), 182 meters deep, was selected for the study. The core age could be estimated at 1670+/- 400 years. The temperature in situ (volcanic caldera) is expected to fluctuate around 0oC. This ice sample contained small-size mineral inclusions and underwent thorough decontamination and processing in clean rooms. Two sub-segments, 182up, and 182bottom, separated by 6.5cm, were treated individually. Genomic DNA was isolated from the concentrated meltwater and amplified using universal degenerate primers targeting the v3-v4 region of bacterial 16S rRNA genes. Initially, the amplicons were sequenced using a common Sanger sequencing approach, but no significant findings were obtained due to contamination and the limited number of clones investigated. Subsequently, the identical amplicons were sequenced using high-throughput Oxford nanopore technology. The sequencing revealed that most reads were contaminants, but around 1% passed all contamination criteria and belonged to the Proteobacteria (phylum Pseudomonadota).Interestingly, the two subsegments of ice contained unique non-overlapping taxa of Proteobacteria, suggesting that the ice in these segments may have been deposited under different local climatic conditions. Thus, the upper-most ice segment showed presence of Methylobacterium tardum, Sphingomonas gilva, Brevundimonas naejangsanensis, Comamonas aquatica, Luteimonas pelagia, and Halomonas (Vreelandella) azerica, while the bottom segment - Paracoccus gahaiensis, Delftia tsuruhatensis, Stenotrophomonas (Pseudomonas) geniculata, and the phylotype related to Acidibacter ferrireducens. Notably, Halomonas azerica, an indicator for cold period depositions (Bulat et al., 2024a, 2024b), was detected in the top 182up sample, indicating that the enclosed snow was deposited during a cold period. This finding suggests that deep terrestrial glaciers may contain diverse Eolian microbial assemblages, which could serve as proxies for local climate changes in the past.

PRJNA1144430.title: Biogeochemistry of the rare sulfidic glaciovolcanic cave system on Mount Meager, British Columbia, Canada
PRJNA1144430.description: These sequencing data are part of the Mount Meager Volcano Project, which aims in part to characterize the microbial ecology of subglacial sediments, glacial melt water, and snow surrounding active subglacial fumaroles at Mt. Meager, British Columbia, Canada.

PRJNA1145506.title: Haima cold seep sediments after microscopic experiment
PRJNA1145506.description: Haima cold seep sediment amended with 0.05% or 0.5% of polyamide (PA), polyethylene (PE), polyethylene terephthalate (PET), and polypropylene (PP) microplastics after 150 days microscopic experiment. Each group repeat three times.

PRJNA1113969.title: Whole Genome Sequencing of Arctic Seawater Marine Isolates
PRJNA1113969.description: Whole genome sequencing of marine microbes sourced from 1m below artic sea ice and enriched on different carbon sources including fructose, palatinose, and laminarin. Isolates are capable of breaking down complex polysaccharides derived from marine algae.

PRJNA1144814.title: Algivorous Cercozoa shape the community composition of biocrusts, the dominant vegetation in the polar regions
PRJNA1144814.description: Soil algae are the most important primary producers where vascular plants are absent, as in the Arctic and Antarctica. They give rise to species-rich microbial food webs in biological soil crusts. The terrestrial snow- and ice-free areas are in permanent expansion as glaciers retreat, leaving behind extensive areas of uncovered rock and new soil. Biological soil crusts stabilize the soil surface and have an important role in soil development. However, the microbial food webs and the nutrient and energy flow to higher trophic levels remain largely unexplored. Here, we characterized the microbial predator-prey dynamics of polar soils by combining molecular and traditional culturing techniques. Using high-throughput sequencing of environmental samples, we assessed the biodiversity and function of soil protists, applying a trait-based approach for acquiring and describing functional traits, i.e., feeding behavior of heterotrophic protists in relation to microalgae.

PRJEB70287.title: Bacterial communities in ARAON Mounds of Chukchi Sea
PRJEB70287.description: 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing of marine sediment microbiomes in ARAON Mounds of Chukchi Sea

PRJNA1142473.title: Soil bacterial community of different grazing intensities under warming and fertilization in Northern Norway (Raisduoddar OTCF grazing experiment)
PRJNA1142473.description: In this study we tested how four years of experimental warming and fertilization affected soil bacterial communities in subarctic mountain tundra areas with decadal history of either heavy or light reindeer grazing. The study consisted of eight replicates of control (C), warming (W), fertilization (F) and combined warming and fertilization (WF) treatments under two contrasting long-term grazing regimes (light (LG) and heavy (HG) grazing, respectively). Warming was implemented with open-top chambers (OTCs) set to the plots from June to July, and fertilization by adding ammonium nitrate solution (NH4NO3, equivalent to 10 g N m-2) to the plots early in the growing season each year. In July 2013, composite soil samples were collected from the organic horizon, homogenized, and characterized for bacterial community composition in duplicate samples using Ion Torrent high-throughput sequencing of 16S rDNA gene region.

PRJNA529480.title: TPA metagenomic assembly of the PRJNA529480 data set
PRJNA529480.description: The Third Party Annotation (TPA) assembly was derived from the primary whole genome shotgun (WGS) dataset PRJNA529480. The assembly was generated with metaSPAdes (Nurk et al., 2017) and metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were reconstructed using MetaBAT2 (Kang et al., 2019) with contig coverage information across multiple samples. Methods are described in Paoli et al., 2022 and Ruscheweyh et al., 2022.

PRJNA1141919.title: Whole Genome of an Antarctic Pseudomonas
PRJNA1141919.description: To study the presence and novelty of antimicrobial genes in Antarctic bacteria.

PRJEB72882.title: Bacterial 16S rRNA community in manganese reducing slurry incubation experiment with sediment of Potter Cove
PRJEB72882.description: An incubation experiment was performed, investigating manganese reduction and the associated microbial community in Antarctic, glacial influenced sediments. Slurry was prepared in a 1:5 ratio of sediment and sulfate-free artificial sea water. The used sediment originated from core STA01.02, 0-25 cm, at station 01 in Potter Cove, King George Island/Isla 25 de Mayo, West Antarctic Peninsula, retrieved in Austral summer 2019. The incubation experiment was performed anoxically for two treatments: birnessite (manganese oxide) + acetate and acetate-only, in biological triplicates, incubated at 2 degrees C in the dark. DNA and RNA were co-extracted and the present and active bacterial community was identified by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing on RNA (cDNA) and DNA level.  Project was funded by DFG SPP 1158

PRJEB72775.title: Longitudinal gut microbiota dynamics in Antarctic research mission crews
PRJEB72775.description: A prolonged stay at Antarctic research stations presents unique challenges because of the extreme environmental conditions, restricted diets, and cold temperatures, which can affect the gut microbiota, an aspect related to host health. However, the effects of the Antarctic environment on the gut microbiota remain uncertain because of the limited number of study participants and short study durations. In this study, we analyzed 467 fecal samples collected longitudinally from 48 participants who stayed at Antarctic stations for up to 16 months. Before departing to the Antarctic bases, male participants exhibited three distinct types of gut microbiota, which were differentially altered during and after the stay, depending on the pre-existing microbiota type. Prevotella-dominant microbiota was more susceptible to environmental changes, including the diet, compared with Bacteroides-dominant microbiota. Although the dominant genera in the gut microbiota were stable across all microbiota types, minor genera with high variability could mediate changes in the microbiota. Sharing diets and having frequent contact resulted in cohabitation effects among genetically unrelated participants in the extremely isolated Antarctic environment. The taxonomic composition was altered while staying at Antarctic bases based on the environment; however, the predicted functions of the gut microbiota were relatively stable over time. Overall, this study shows the impact of staying in remote Antarctic stations on the gut microbiota and indicates its alteration based on intrinsic microbiota prior to the mission.

PRJEB75226.title: Is sea ice ridge formation sustaining ice-associated ecosystem activity during Arctic winter?
PRJEB75226.description: To investigate the role of sea ice ridging in providing organic matter that can sustain microbial winter activity several DNA samples were taken for the HAVOC project as part of the Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of the Arctic Climate (MOSAiC) expedition. This study was done in the Arctic Ocean during leg 2 of MOSAiC, when RV Polarstern was drifting with an ice floe from 86.6 °N, 118.4°E on Dec 13, 2019 to 88.6°N, 61.3°E on Feb 23, 2020 in the eastern Amundsen Basin (Krumpen et al. 2020, Nicolaus et al. 2022). The sampling for the study was performed in the Central Observatory (CO) close to Polarstern, including the on ice oceanography site Ocean City and the MOSAiC sea ice coring site (MCS). A Sea Ice Ridge Observatory (SIRO) was established during leg 2 at a ridge in the CO named Fort Ridge. The ridge keel studied was approximately 100 m long and 20 m wide. DNA was extracted from water samples (250 – 500 mL) from 20 and 1000 m depth (10.02.2020), from a water- filled void inside the ridge (at 204-224 cm below the ice surface; 24.01.2020), a gypsum net tow (08.02.2020) and melted sea ice samples from FYI (ice interior; 03.02.2020), SYI (60-70 cm, 70-80 cm, 80-93 cm; 13.01.2020) and ridge ice above and below the water-filled void (157- 204 cm; 224 -  260 cm; 24.01.2020). The DNA was extracted and prepared for paired-end MiSeq sequencing (Illumina, CA, USA) using a two-step PCR method to amplify the V1 to V3 region of the eukaryotic 18S rRNA  genes and the V4 region of the bacterial and archaeal 16SrRNA genes before attaching MiSeq adapter and barcode sequences.

PRJEB53455.title: particle-attached microbial diversity during the AT2018 cruise to the Arctic Ocean
PRJEB53455.description: RV Akademik Tryoshnikov left Arkhangelsk on August 17 2018, and on August 22-30 for observations in the western part of the Laptev Sea under the auspice of CATS (The Changing Arctic Transpolar System)/Transdrift program.   water samples for microbial diversity from 40-60L for the big size fraction (Large particles > 100µm, denoted as 'LD') and 2L for the small size fraction (particles < 100µm, denoted as 'SD'). All samples were prefiltered through 100µm nylon mesh. For the large size fraction particles from the pre-filter were flushed onto 0.22µm Sterivex filters and filtrate was pumped for the small size fraction onto 0.22µm Sterivex filters using a Masterflex pump and silicone hoses.  Samples were stored in -80° until DNA extraction. Sequencing was performed using an Illumina MiSeq at the AWI, Bremerhaven, Germany.

PRJEB73478.title: Exploring the diversity of Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae isolates from the Canadian Arctic
PRJEB73478.description: This study explores the genomic diversity of E. rhusiopathiae isolated from various host species from across the Canadian Arctic.

PRJEB77092.title: Amplicon sequencing of Arctic microphytobenthic communities (Kongsfjorden, Svalbard, August-September 2022)
PRJEB77092.description: Fungal parasites of microalgae are crucial yet often overlooked in aquatic food webs, as they influence microbial interactions, accelerate nutrient transfer and control host population dynamics. In the rapidly warming Arctic, increased glacier meltwater significantly impacts coastal microphytobenthic communities. Dominated by benthic diatoms, which are preferential hosts for fungal parasites, these communities represent a key component in the functioning of Arctic trophic food webs. In this project, we conducted amplicon sequencing of sediment samples from different locations around Kongsfjorden (Svalbard, Norway), collected along a salinity gradient between August and September 2022.
PRJEB77092.center_name: leibniz-institute of freshwater ecology and inland fisheries

PRJNA1137255.title: Linking Biogenic High-Temperature Ice Nucleating Particles in Arctic soils and Streams to Their Microbial Producers
PRJNA1137255.description: Aerosols, including biological aerosols, exert a significant influence on cloud formation, influencing the global climate through their effects on radiative balance and precipitation. The Arctic region features persistent mixed-phase clouds, which are impacted by ice nucleating particles (INPs) that modulate the phase transitions within clouds, affecting their lifetime and impacting the region's climate. An increasing number of studies document that Arctic soils harbour a large number of biogenic INPs (bioINPs), but these have yet to be linked to their microbial producers. In addition, the transfer of bioINPs from soils into freshwater and marine systems has not been quantified. This study aimed at addressing these open questions by analyzing soil and freshwater samples from Northeast Greenland to determine the microbial composition along with the INP concentrations and size distributions. We found that soils contained between 3 x 104 and 6 x 106 INP g-1 soil, which was on the lower side of what has previously been reported for permafrost soils. The composition of INPs varied widely across locations and could have originated from bacterial and fungal sources. We found that Mortierella, a fungal genus known to produce ice-nucleating proteins, was present in nearly all samples. Spearman correlations between soil taxa and INP concentrations pointed at lichenized fungi as a possible contributor to soil INP. Additionally, based on the INP size distribution, we suggest that soil INPs were bound to soil particles or microbial membranes at some locations, while other locations showed a variety of soluble INPs with different molecular sizes. In streams, INP concentrations and onset temperatures were comparable to what has previously been measured in streams from temperate regions. Interestingly, stream INP concentrations showed a positive association with soil INP concentrations. The presence of highly active INPs in Arctic regions holds implications for mixed-phase cloud properties and climate, revealing the significant, yet complex, role that soil and stream bioINPs play in the Arctic ecosystem. This research contributes valuable knowledge to the understanding of microbial communities and the potential producers of highly active bioINPs in Arctic soil microbial communities and their connectivity with Arctic streams.

PRJNA1114625.title: Promoting Plant Growth in Cold Environments: A Study on the Functional and Genomic Traits of Ewingella and Pseudomonas Endophytes
PRJNA1114625.description: This study focuses on Ewingella sp. S1.OA.A_B6 and Pseudomonas sp. S2.OTC.A_B10, cold-tolerant endophytic bacteria isolated from Antarctic pearlwort (Colobanthus quitensis). These bacteria, as part of the complex microbial communities in cold environments, enhance plant growth under cold stress. Our aim is to explore the functional and genomic characteristics that enable these bacteria to promote plant growth and mitigate cold stress.

PRJNA1129510.title: Cultivation based population genomics of under sea ice bacteria
PRJNA1129510.description: This project uses a cultivation based approach to explore bacterial community and population diversity in arctic under ice seawater. It provides high quality closed genomes and cultures for previously uncultured families, genera, and species of marine bacteria.

PRJNA1129571.title: Sequencing Zoonotic Bacterial Pathogens in Ukraine
PRJNA1129571.description: Scientific initiative to understand genetic diversity and antimicrobial resistance patterns among bacterial zoonoses in Ukraine

PRJNA1126602.description: This study significantly adds to the knowledge of bacterial biodiversity in glacier communities through the use of metagenomic analysis. The microbiota of Altai cryoconites has a complex structure. There are various complexes of species that have different origins and routes of entry.
PRJNA1126602.center_name: Komarov Botanical Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences

PRJNA1107577.title: Full length sequences and assemblies of genomes from arctic ground squirrel gut microbes
PRJNA1107577.description: A collection of whole genome sequences and assemblies from microbial isolates cultured from hibernators for the purpose of defining the gut microbes potential contributions to host physiology.

PRJNA1120254.title: Effects on cold-adapted heterotrophic nitrification and denitrification Pseudomonas sp. NY1 by cupric ions: Performance and mechanism
PRJNA1120254.description: In this study, a cold-adapted and efficient nitrogen removal bacterium Pseudomonas sp. NY1was isolated and identified from the soil. By adding different concentrations of cupric ions to investigate the characteristics and mechanisms on strain NY1, with a aim of providing a advanced understand and application of the mechanisms and nitrogen removal under cupric ions-containing wastewater.

PRJNA1118335.title: Svalbard soil microbial communities
PRJNA1118335.description: This study uses DNA stable isotope probing to understand microbial community growth in thawing Svalbard soil. We thawed soil from different depths of a frozen permafrost core in the laboratory to trace growth, death, and dormancy in Svalbard soil microbial communities upon thaw.

PRJNA999330.title: Genome sequencing of desert bacterial isolates
PRJNA999330.description: Genome sequencing of desert bacterial isolates from Chile
PRJNA999330.center_name: Instituto de Nutricion y Tecnologia de los Alimentos (INTA)

PRJNA1112440.title: Genome sequencing of high Arctic hypersaline spring derived sulfur oxidizing bacteria
PRJNA1112440.description: Recently, multi-omics analysis of Lost Hammer and Gypsum Hill spring sediment samples uncovered an active predominantly lithoautotrophic microbial community driven largely by sulfur oxidizing bacteria (SOB) amid low oxygen, sub-zero and hypersaline conditions. While sulfur oxidation is thought to drive primary production in these environments and is considered a possible Mars relevant metabolism very few SOB have been successfully isolated from cold Arctic hypersaline environments. Metagenomic sequencing approaches have allowed for culture-independent profiling of these communities, but their metabolic and physiological traits remain largely uncharacterized due to fastidious growth requirements. Overcoming this barrier, multi-omics informed metabolic predictions coupled with traditional enrichment techniques have the potential to enable cultivation of previously uncharacterized polar SOB. This strategy can ultimately help to uncover the cold adapted bioenergetic capabilities of novel cryophilic SOB as well as traits that could allow analogous life in extraterrestrial environments.

PRJNA1114631.title: In vitro rumen microbiome with differing buffer ratio
PRJNA1114631.description: The aim of this study was to determine how the rumen bacterial community of cattle changed within a batch in vitro model of fermentation over 6hr periods (0-48hrs) with three different ratios of rumen fluid to buffer as commonly seen in the literature (1 in 2, 1 in 4 and 1 in 9)

PRJNA1047647.title: 16S microbiome of larvae and juveniles of Gigantidas childressi
PRJNA1047647.description: The goals of this study were to describe microbial community dynamics during key life-history transitions in the chemosymbiotic, deep-sea mussel Gigantidas childressi. Despite many studies targeting their specific chemosynthetic symbionts, the microbiome of this unique and ecologically relevant host has never been investigated. We sequenced the V3-V4 regions of the 16S rRNA gene, targeting bacterial DNA present in veligers, pediveligers, small juveniles, and adult gill snips.

PRJNA1109674.title: Amplicon sequencing data of the ice core samples from Frey-peak, Rathong and Kabru Glaciers of West Sikkim, India
PRJNA1109674.description: The bacterial diversity of the ice core samples retrieved from the three glaciers of West Sikkim viz. Frey-Peak, Rathong, and Kabru Glacier were studied using 16SrRNA gene amplicon sequencing. The ice core samples were collected from the accumulation zone of the glacier, using ice corer machine(1.5m length, KOVAC's Enterprise) and in the laboratory it was further processed in the positive laminar airflow.

PRJNA1108631.title: Paraescarpia echinospica and Sclerolinum tubeworm symbiont metagenome
PRJNA1108631.description: Paraescarpia echinospica and Sclerolinum tubeworms were collected from the Haima Cold seep in the South China Sea. Paraescarpia echinospica was sampled in April 2023 at latitude and longitude (110.27E, 16.435N). Sclerolinum was sampled in July 2022 using the ROV robot. Paraescarpia echinospica was dissected with a sterile scalpel and scissors and sampled from the trophosome site. In contrast, Sclerolinum tubes were too thin and soft to be separated from the tissue, so the entire Sclerolinum was sampled directly. The samples were rinsed with DNA extraction buffer (100 mM Tris HCl, 100 mM EDTA, 100 mM Na2HPO4, 1.5 M NaCl, 1% CTAB, pH 8.0) to eliminate any remaining surface impurities and preservatives. Subsequently, the tissue blocks were placed in 1 mL of DNA extraction buffer, which was adequately cut and left to stand with sterile scissors. The upper suspension containing microbial cells was collected after the large pieces of tissue were precipitated. The microorganisms were ultimately precipitated through high-speed centrifugation. The resulting microbial precipitates were obtained for macrogenetics studies. The DNA was extracted and purified using a magnetic bead-based soil and fecal genomic DNA extraction kit (TIANGEN) according to the manufacturer's protocol. Qualitative and quantitative analysis was performed on the purified DNA using a Qubit 4.0 device and agarose gel electrophoresis with 1% agarose. The VAHTS Universal Plus DNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina was used for metagenomic library construction according to the manufacturer's protocol.Genome assembly was performed on the symbionts of Paraescarpia echinospica (Hai6C03) and Sclerolinum (SCTW1H) collected from Cold Seep, South China Sea. The Hai6C03 assembled genome had a size of 4,171,724 bp, a GC content of 54.43%, a completeness degree of 99.33%, and a contamination degree of 1.6%. The genome assembled by SCTW1H was 2,832,488 bp in size with a GC content of 50.46%. Its completeness was 94.72%, and the contamination degree was 0.23%.

PRJNA1108919.title: Terrestrial runoff is the dominant source of a new type of biological INPs observed in Arctic fjords
PRJNA1108919.description: The excellerated warming of the Arctic manifests in e.g., the thawing of permafrost, the loss of sea ice and the melting of glaciers. Glacial run-off increases the input of freshwater, sediments, and nutrients into fjords and coastal waters. The decrease in sea-ice cover and the loss of albedo results in firstly, increased radiation reaching through the water column and secondly, increased temperatures which both significantly alters the dynamics of the marine biota, e.g., leading to increased gross primary production. Previous studies indicate that marine areas are sources of biological material with ice nucleating properties and it has been suggested that these particles stem from algal exudates released during phytoplanktonic blooms. Rising temperatures may result in increased microbial activity, thereby influencing the concentration and characteristics of ice nucleating particles (INPs) in seawater. However, various microorganisms, which inhabit marine and terrestrial environments, are shown to produce ice nucleating active material. Thus, terrestrial environments can also be a source of INPs transported to the sea water by e.g. rivers and streams. Additionally, outwash of glacial sediment and permafrost soil contain highly active biological INPs that may be released in increasing numbers into the coastal ecosystem. The biological INPs can then be transferred from the marine areas into the atmosphere by wave breaking and bubble bursting and can subsequently be transported to higher altitudes where they may trigger the freezing of cloud droplets. Thereby, they would impact the lifetime of clouds as well as their radiative properties. Despite our knowledge of the presence of INPs in marine environments and possible impact on atmospheric processes, our understanding of both their characteristics and sources remains limited. To address these knowledge gaps, we sampled sea bulk water and sea surface microlayer between June and September 2018 in two southwest Greenlandic fjords and investigated the ice-nucleating particles along with the microbial community composition of both algae and bacteria present in these two marine compartments. Our study reveals a clear seasonal variation in the number and types of INPs. We found the highest concentration in June during the late stage of a phytoplanktonic bloom. Using filtration and heat treatments, we found that the highly active INPs found in June are smaller in size, and less heat sensitive compared to the INPs present in July and September, thus indicating different INP types and origin. A strong negative correlation between the number of INPs and salinity suggests inputs from either glacial melt water or sea ice melt as a potential source of INPs or a combination of both. However, stable oxygen isotope analysis pointed to meteoric water such as river runoff as the major source of the observed freshwater input indicating that the highly active INPs stem from a terrestrial source.

PRJNA1095873.title: Antarctic granites metadata
PRJNA1095873.description: The Antarctic continent harbors unique ecosystems, including diverse microbial communities inhabiting rocky substrates. Despite extensive research on Antarctic microbial ecology, a gap in knowledge persists regarding the comparative analysis of microbial communities associated with Antarctic granite and epilithic lichen environments. This study addresses the lack of research on both endolithic communities in granite and epilithic communities represented by lichens in Antarctica. Moreover, this study represents the first comparative analysis between these two ecologies, providing valuable insights into their microbial diversity and composition. We addressed this gap by conducting a comprehensive comparative analysis of microbial communities colonizing granite surfaces in Antarctica, focusing on both endolithic and epilithic niches. Through high-throughput sequencing approaches, we characterized the fungal and bacterial diversity associated with these environments. Our results revealed distinct differences between endolithic and epilithic communities in terms of diversity and composition. Endolithic communities exhibited higher microbial diversity, likely influenced by a combination of environmental factors and the complex interplay between lichens and other microorganisms. Moreover, cyanobacteria were found to play a significant role in endolithic communities, demonstrating their adaptability to low-light conditions and their importance in nutrient cycling. Overall, our findings shed light on the ecological dynamics of microbial communities in extreme environments and highlight the importance of further research to elucidate their roles in Antarctic ecosystems.

PRJNA1092253.title: The chemosynthetic microbiome of deep-sea hydrothermal vents across space and time
PRJNA1092253.description: Microbial biofilms colonize mineral and biological substrates exposed to fluid circulation at deep-sea hydrothermal vents, providing a biologically active interface along redox boundaries. Since many biofilms at deep-sea vents are associated with invertebrates, microbial distribution and abundance are not only constrained by local fluid geochemistry, but also through host-microbe interactions. In this study, we examined the spatial distribution and diversity of established microbial biofilm communities collected from three distinct biological regimes characteristic of the East Pacific Rise vent system, as well as newly established biofilms.

PRJNA1088749.title: Novel oil-associated bacteria in Arctic seawater exposed to different nutrient biostimulation regimes
PRJNA1088749.description: This study provides insights into the microbial community of seawater collected in Canada's Kitikmeot Sea amended with crude oil in microcosm and incubated at 4 celsius degrees over 15 weeks.

PRJNA1090395.title: Bacterial Diversity of the lakes and  Glaciers of Larsemann Hills
PRJNA1090395.description: The study of microbial diversity in the Antarctic Dalk Glacier is of great significance in understanding the biological mechanisms of microorganisms in extreme environments, enriching the microbial diversity of the Antarctic region, and providing a reference for the development of Antarctic extreme microbial strain resources.

PRJNA1090689.title: Whole-genome sequencing of Flavobacterium psychrophilum and Flavobacterium branchiophilum
PRJNA1090689.description: In this study, whole-genome sequencing of seven Flavobacterium psychrophilum and two Flavobacterium branchiophilum isolates from Slovenian fish farms was performed.

PRJNA1090233.title: Seasonal variation modifies the response patterns of abundant and rare fungal groups in a permafrost ecosystem
PRJNA1090233.description: Soil freeze-thaw is a common phenomenon at high latitude permafrost regions, and it can alter soil physical properties and microbial diversity. However, how the abundant and rare fungal groups respond to environmental temperature changes (i.e., seasonal variations), particularly freeze-thaw events, are still not well understood. In this study, we investigated the dynamics of soil properties, fungal community diversity, structure, and co-occurrence network in a typical seasonally frozen ecosystem, we sampled three times during the non-freeze-thaw period, freeze-thaw period, and freezing period, respectively. Our findings revealed that significant variations in the fungal community diversity were detected at different sampling stages. Notably, abundant and rare fungal taxa exhibited the differential response patterns. Compared to the non-freeze-thaw period, freeze-thaw cycling reduced the alpha diversity of the abundant fungal taxa, but increased the alpha diversity of rare fungal taxa. We also found that changes in community composition of rare taxa were more senstive to environmental temperature changes than abundant taxa, and they contributed more to the stability of co-occurrence network. Soil moisture content, organic carbon, total nitrogen, and total phosphorus were the primary factors affecting fungal community structure. Although soil pH had no significant impact on fungal community structure, it exhibited significant correlations with the rare taxa of p_Chytridiomycota and p_Mucoromycota. Overall, the study results provide useful information on the prediction of soil microorganisms in response to environmental temperature changes in seasonally permafrost regions under the background of global warming.

PRJNA1080106.description: Snow depth influences soil temperatures and moisture especially during the winter, spring and early summer season. To understand how the microbial community composition and diversity is affected by these parameters, we investigated bacterial and fungal amplicon-generated sequences of the 16S rRNA gene and ITS.

PRJNA1046711.title: root-associated fungal community in changing tundra
PRJNA1046711.description: Climate warming is severely threatening ecosystems at high latitudes. In the Arctic tundra, it may lead to enhanced soil nutrient availability, and interact with simultaneous changes in grazing pressure. It is presently unknown how these concurrently occurring global change drivers affect the root-associated fungal communities, particularly mycorrhizal fungi, and whether changes coincide with shifts in plant mycorrhizal types.This study aims at investigating changes in root-associated fungal communities and mycorrhizal types of the plant community in a 10-year factorial experiment with warming, fertilisation, and grazing exclusion in a Finnish tundra meadow.

PRJNA1084073.title: Marine Aerosols in the Arctic: Linking surface water chemistry and biology with primary particle production
PRJNA1084073.description: Investigate linkages between surface water biology and chemistry with primary atmospheric particle production in the central Arctic Ocean during a fall icebreaker cruise (2018)

PRJNA605861.title: Genome sequencing of Antarctic bacteria
PRJNA605861.description: The Antarctic bacteria is an untapped environment proposed as a promising source of new drugs. Genomes and evolution studies on this microorganisms are limited. The aim of this project is to provide genomic data for further studies and genome mining on Antarctic bacteria.

PRJEB59938.title: Microbial methane production associated with permafrost soils in Yedoma (Alaska) upland forested and grassland hillslopes. We show that upland forested and grassland hillslopes with thermokarst features initiated in the last 50 to 70 years by thawing of ice-rich yedoma permafrost soils are an exceptionally large source of microbial 14C-depleted methane, especially in winter when surface soils freeze, limiting methanotrophy.
PRJEB59938.description: Microbial methane production associated with permafrost soils has been considered only in the seasonally thawed active layer and in inundated thermokarst lake and wetland sedimentsWalzEtAl2017,Turetsky2020NatGeo. Until now, dry, upland soils that dominate 87% of the ArcticHugeliusetal2014, are assumed to be an atmospheric methane sink that compensates for much of the northern wetland-derived feedbacks to climate warming this centuryOhEtAl2020. Contrary evidence about the role of uplands would require a paradigm shift leading to a new framework for understanding the permafrost carbon feedback. Here we used field-flux measurements, radiocarbon dating and borehole drilling to show that talik (thaw bulb) development in yedoma permafrost soils leads to large methane emissions in dry upland environments. Eddy covariance methane emissions from a graminoid-dominated hillslope with thermokarst-mounds were three times higher annually than wetland emissions from the same latitude. Seventy percent of upland emissions occurred in winter, when surface soils were frozen, shutting down the powerful capacity of methane oxidizing bacteria, but permitting escape of methane produced in underlying anoxic taliks. These findings require restructuring our framework of permafrost carbon feedback trajectories to climate change, and imply that methane emission from upland taliks has the potential to overwhelm methane consumption by surface soils.
PRJEB59938.center_name: the department of earth and environmental sciences at bgu

PRJNA1081369.title: Study of the Aerobic Methanotrophic Bacterial Community in Antarctic Environments: Impact of Temperature Evaluated through PLFA-SIP
PRJNA1081369.description: Amplicon sequence of partial gene 16S rRNA from phospholipid fatty acid profiling stable isotope probing (PLFA-SIP) assay of lake sediments of Antarctic origin (King George Island, Fildes Peninsula) at different incubation temperatures

PRJNA1079543.title: Microbial diversity and functional feature of low-temperature Daqu from Taiyuan and Suizhou regions
PRJNA1079543.description: To investigate the microbial community and functional features of low-temperature Daqu, twenty samples oflow-temperature Daqu were colltected from Taiyuan City, Shanxi Province and Suizhou County, Hubei Province, China, and were submitted to shotgun metagenomics sequencing.

PRJNA1075763.title: Tundra moss transplants reveal host species-specific microbial communities and independent responses of associated N2 fixation rates to environmental change
PRJNA1075763.description: This study investigates how climate, moss species, and microbial communities affect N2 fixation in the Alaskan tundra. OUr team conducted a transplant experiment study using two sites that differed in temperature, Healy and Toolik Lake, Alaska, and three moss speices: Hylocomium splendens, Aulacomnium turgidum, and Pleurozium schreberi. Our research combined 16S rRNA gene sequencing with 15N2 incubations. Results showed that N2 fixation rates were influenced more by climate and moss physiology than by microbial community shifts. Pleurozium schreberi increased N2 fixation in cooler conditions, while Aulacomnium turgidum's fixation rates were high regardless of location. This study highlights the complex interplay between biologic and physiochemical variables affecting nitrogen cycling in warming tundra ecosystems.

PRJNA1071343.title: Effects of Laminaria japonica extract supplementation on lactation performance, antioxidant status, immune function, rumen fermentation, and rumen microbiota in late-lactating dairy cows
PRJNA1071343.description: The present study aimed to evaluate the effects of Laminaria japonica extract (LJE) on supplementation on feed intake, lactation performance, blood antioxidant and immunity, rumen fermentation and rumen microbiota of late-lactating Holstein dairy cows. Thirty-two healthy lactating Holstein dairy cows with similar body weight, milk yield and days in milk were selected and randomly assigned to two dietary groups, receiving either a basal dietor the CON diet supplemented with LJE .
PRJNA1071343.center_name: Institute of Subtropical Agriculture, Chinese Academy of Sciences

PRJEB50515.title: Bacterial and fungal community structure in tundra soil after two-decadal warming and simulated herbivory treatment
PRJEB50515.description: Responses of the Arctic ecosystems to global climate change is of great importance due to the massive amounts of carbon stored in the high latitudes. Global warming is increasing the abundance and distribution of deciduous shrubs which is feared to increase soil microbial activities and lead to increased C losses from the soil to the atmosphere. The effect of herbivores in these ecosystems may be substantial and it has been suggested that herbivores may counteract warming-induced spread of shrubs and influence the responses of the ecosystem carbon balances to warming. In this study we characterized the bacterial and fungal community structure after two decadal experimental warming and simulated herbivory treatment in an arctic alpine tundra ecosystem in northern Finland.

PRJNA1071093.title: Experimentally created Antarctic cryoconite holes
PRJNA1071093.description: We used an in situ manipulative experiment to test whether the order in which community members arrive determines the composition of microbial communities on glaciers in the Dry Valleys of Antarctica. Here we show that strong priority effects were evident after the first growing season on the glacier, but that these effects were dampened after a second growing season likely due to strong selection by the harsh environment. These findings broaden our understanding of factors driving the biodiversity of the cryobiosphere at a time when it is severely threatened by global warming.

PRJEB66269.title: Oedenwinkel field and experiment
PRJEB66269.description: The study contains 16S sequences of soil samples for comparing the field samples and experiment samples of Oedenwinkelkees glacier.
PRJEB66269.center_name: University of California San Diego Microbiome Initiative

PRJEB60815.title: Arctic microbiome along Svalbard Cross Shelf transects (2019 Campaign)
PRJEB60815.description: Microbiome analysis of seawater samples collected at stations along Svalbard Cross Shelf transects, at different depths and replicated for three distinct sequencing strategies: V4-V5 16S rRNA gene, full-length 16S rRNA gene and Shotgun metagenomics).  Samples were collected during the Norwegian Polar Institute MOSJ-ICE 2019 plankton-monitoring program. Samples were concentrated on board through Sterivex 0.2 mm filtration and preserved at -80ºC for later DNA extraction.The V4-V5 16S rRNA gene and Shotgun metagenomics was sequenced by Illumina and the full-length 16S rRNA gene was sequenced by PacBio CCS.  This dataset will be expanded in the future, in order to have samples taken at the same geographic locations and with the same methodologies, during different years. Furthermore, this dataset is integrated with the MOSJ 2016 dataset, already made available (MGYS00003725)
PRJEB60815.center_name: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

PRJNA1069645.title: Evidence of habitat specificity in sponge microbiomes from Antarctica.
PRJNA1069645.description: Exploration of the extent of habitat specificity in the community composition, diversity, and microbial co-occurrence within Antarctic sponge microbiomes, compared to sponge microbiomes from other environments, using massive sequencing of 16S rRNA genes.

PRJNA1069634.title: Characterization of Eukaryotic Microbial Communities associated to Antarctic Sponge
PRJNA1069634.description: V4 amplicon of 18S rRNA from Antarctic sponge

PRJEB72034.title: Arctic microbiome along Svalbard Cross Shelf transects (2020 Campaign)
PRJEB72034.description: Microbiome analysis of seawater samples collected at stations along Svalbard Cross Shelf transects (Kongsfjorden), at different depths, based on V4-V5 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing, using Illumina.  Samples were collected during the Norwegian Polar Institute MOSJ-ICE 2018 plankton-monitoring program. Samples were concentrated on board through Sterivex 0.2 mm filtration and preserved at -80ºC for later DNA extraction.  This dataset is part of a standardized effort for a long-term analysis of microbiome data collected at the same geographic locations and with the same methodologies, during different years. Other datasets already publicly available integrated in this long-term effort include MOSJ2016 (MGYS00003725), MOSJ2017, MOSJ2018 and MOSJ2019.
PRJEB72034.center_name: CIIMAR - Interdisciplinary Centre of Marine and Environmental Research

Samples were collected during the Norwegian Polar Institute MOSJ-ICE 2018 plankton-monitoring program. Samples were concentrated on board through Sterivex 0.2 mm filtration and preserved at -80ºC for later DNA extraction.  This dataset is part of a standardized effort for a long-term analysis of microbiome data collected at the same geographic locations and with the same methodologies, during different years. Other datasets already publicly available integrated in this long-term effort include MOSJ2016 (MGYS00003725), MOSJ2017, MOSJ2019 and MOSJ2020.

PRJEB64296.title: 16S V4V5 and ITS2 amplicon from soil communities in a mycorrhiza-removal experiment
PRJEB64296.description: This dataset supports Kirchhoff et al., "Microbial community composition unaffected by mycorrhizal plant removal in sub-arctic tundra" 2024, Fungal Ecology (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.funeco.2024.101342). The dataset consists in amplicon sequencing data of 16S V4V5 and ITS2 of soil communities in a plant removal experiment based on mycorrhizal status at a sub-arctic forest-tundra ecotone. Each sample was analyzed prior to the experiment and after two years of manipulation. In addition, root endophytic fungi were targeted with ITS2 primers on 27 plant species found at the site, both with and without preliminary bleaching to remove rhizosphere-associated fungi. 16S paired-end reads are raw except for demultiplexing carried out through Illumina's software, ITS2 amplicon demultiplexing was done prior to upload according to SCATA processing of the original .ccs read file. The raw .ccs file can be found at https://git.bolin.su.se/bolin/kirchhoff-2024-mycorrhiza-1.0.0 The experimental design and further details are found in Kirchhoff et al., 2024, DOI https://doi.org/10.1016/j.funeco.2024.101342, bioinformatics and data processing scripts are found at https://doi.org/10.57669/kirchhoff-2024-treeline-mycorrhiza-1.0.0
PRJEB64296.center_name: UiT The Arctic University of Norway

PRJNA1068006.title: Highly heterogeneous mycobiota shape fungal diversity in two globally distributed lichens
PRJNA1068006.description: Lichens are multi-kingdom symbioses in which fungi, algae and bacteria interact todevelop a stable selection unit. In addition to the mycobiont forming the symbiosis,fungal communities associated with lichens represent the lichen mycobiota. Theirdiversity is still largely unknown, we therefore aim to characterize it in two cosmopolitanlichens, i.e., Rhizoplaca melanophthalma and Tephromela atra. The mycobiota wereinvestigated across a broad range of their distribution using both a culture-dependentapproach and environmental DNA metabarcoding. The variation of the mycobiotaassociated with the two lichen species is extremely high, and a stable species-specificcore mycobiota is hardly identifiable. Most of the mycobiota taxa are present in a lowfraction of the samples, and no taxon is ubiquitously present in either lichen species.The mycobiota are thus composed of heterogeneous fungi, and some taxa aredetectable only by the culture-dependent approach. We suspect that lichens act asniches in which these fungi may exploit the thallus resources, while only a few mayestablish more stable trophic relationships with the major symbiotic partners.

PRJNA1067112.title: Effect of Zero-Valent Iron (ZVI) on nitrogen and iron metabolism in the Anammox-Hydroxyapatite (HAP) system under low-temperature shock

PRJNA1067178.title: Low-temperature denitrification bacteria
PRJNA1067178.description: Screening and performance testing of low-temperature denitrification bacteria

PRJEB50265.title: Drivers of bacterial community structure in a gold bearing sub-Arctic soil ecosystem
PRJEB50265.description: Soil microbial communities drive geochemical cycles and recently it has been shown that the transport of even inert metals, such as gold, may be microbially driven. In this study the linkages between soil bacterial community structure and geochemical factors were investigated in a metallogenic sub-Arctic soil. Samples were obtained from gold and rare earth element (REE) enriched soils located in Mäkärä, Lapland, Northern Finland. Soil was sampled from the B horizon of nine sites around a gold-hematite quartz vein and one control site outside the mineralization. In addition, hematite samples were obtained from an excavated research trench.  Bacterial community structure in the soil and hematite samples was characterized by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing using Ion Torrent technology. Geochemical parameters of the soil samples were analyzed, and geochemical drivers of the bacterial community structure evaluated by multivariate methods. A particular interest was to identify linkages between gold and soil bacteria in an attempt to identify signature taxa associated with gold anomalies.

PRJNA1063326.title: Biosynthetic Genes Clusters with Biotechnological Applications in Novel Antarctic isolates from Actinomycetota
PRJNA1063326.description: This study aimed to explore the metabolic potential of Actinomycetota strains isolated from Antarctic soils and sediment samples. The significance lies in uncovering new, rare Actinomycetota strains and their unique BGCs, which hold promise for developing various applications such as antimicrobials, anticancer agents, and plant growth promoters. This exploration in extreme environments like Antarctica opens doors to innovative biotechnological advancements and new opportunities for beneficial microbial products.

PRJNA1062590.title: Bacterial community response during PAH degradation
PRJNA1062590.description: High-throughput sequencing was employed to explore the changes in the bacterial community during biodegradation and find the key and potential contributors to PAH degradation in the enriched bacterial consortia.

PRJNA1055571.title: Microbiome of Antarctic polychaetes
PRJNA1055571.description: This study provides new insights into the knowledge of the microbiomes associated with three polychaetes species living in three areas of the Ross Sea, characterized by different envitonmental features. We also compared microbiomes associated with the seastars and the bacterial assemblages living in the sourrunding sediments, to investigate the origin of these associations.
PRJNA1055571.center_name: Stazione Zoologica Anton Dohrn - Fano Marine Center

PRJNA1046404.title: Northwest Passage baseline beach metagenomes
PRJNA1046404.description: We performed a baseline survey by sequencing the metagenomes of the microbial communities of 9 beaches located along the Northwest Passage in the Canadian high Arctic. We aimed to determine if there is genomic potential for hydrocarbon biodegradation present in these presumably pristine beaches. This will help us understand whether bioremediation could be a feasible cleanup solution in case of a hydrocarbon spill from a passing ship ever washes up to one of these beaches.

PRJNA356108.title: Alaskan tundra lake, stream, and soil microbiomes
PRJNA356108.description: Microbial communities carry out critical processes that regulate the amounts and forms of important nutrients and carbon, which are essential for all ecosystem services on Earth. Microbial biodiversity and ecosystem functions are controlled (1) by local environmental conditions that affect growth, and (2) by dispersal via wind and water; however, the relative importance of these factors is not well understood. This research project characterized these two fundamental controls on the distribution and activity of microbes in arctic lakes, streams, and soils, and revealed how seasonal, annual, and long-term shifts in microbial species are affected by climate change. These goals were achieved with a multi-year study of microbial community composition and growth rate in arctic lakes and streams on the North Slope of Alaska. This research used the data archive of environmental measurements produced by the Arctic Long Term Ecological Research program (LTER).

PRJNA1047131.title: Arctic marine sediment metagenome Targeted loci environmental
PRJNA1047131.description: Thermophilic spore-forming anaerobes are present as dormant spores in cold marine sediments. Our work shows that in the Arctic, these thermospores are derived from warm marine subsurface ecosystems, such as hydrothermal fluid flow at mid-ocean ridges or deeply buried petroleum reservoirs, and then dispersed by ocean currents to marine sediments. Because these organisms are present in the Arctic as inactive spores that are buried in sediments over time, analysis of thermospore diversity along sediment depth cores provides a unique window into their evolutionary history and the ecological history of their deep biosphere sources. Therefore, our objective is to characterise the diversity and community composition of thermospores along two Arctic sediment depth cores, representing approximately 500 years, by using thermospore enrichment incubations followed by 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing. Changes in diversity with depth will be analysed by traditional OTU-based approaches combined with analysis of microdiversity within OTUs using Minimum Entropy Decomposition. We hypothesise that both OTU-level composition and fine-scale diversity within OTUs will vary with depth. Broader changes at the OTU-level will provide evidence of ecological or physical change within the subsurface habitats, while changes in microdiversity will reflect the evolutionary history of individual populations. This project is a novel step towards reconstructing both the evolutionary and ecological history of subsurface microbes. PI: China Hanson, School of Biological and Chemical Sciences, Queen Mary University of London.

PRJEB9144.title: Analyzing the deep biosphere of up to 3.6 million years old El’gygytgyn Crater Lake sediments
PRJEB9144.description: Our study is a marker-gene-based investigation of deep sediments of the arctic crater lake El'gygytygn. Sediment cores were drilled during an ICDP expedition. The sediments range to 317m depths which corresponds to a sediment age of 3.6 million years. Geochemical parameters for the cores have been determined. For biological analysis, we applied qPCR and MiSeq 16S rRNA analysis for 57 samples and looked for correlations to geochemical parameters and paleo-climatological conditions.
PRJEB9144.center_name: GFZ German Research Centre for Geosciences

PRJNA1042949.title: THALLI
PRJNA1042949.description: The sampling campaign took place during the Antarctic expedition November 2021- February 2022. In this campaign, 14 selected localities have been visited in the northern Victoria Land, within the south latitudinal range from the 72 to 77 parallel (Table 1). At least three individuals of each selected lichen species, when present and feasible to collect, were sampled in each locality. The samples were aseptically removed with the rock substrate using a geological hammer, placed into sterile plastic bags, and stored dry at -20 C, also during the transportation to the laboratories, until downstream analyses.The following lichen species were collected and used for the molecular analyses: the endemic Antarctic Acarospora flavocordia, Buellia frigida, Lecanora fuscobrunnea, Lecanora physciella, Lecidea cancriformis, and the cosmopolitan Pleopsidium chlorophanum, Rhizoplaca melanophthalma, Rusavskia elegans. Along the study they will be referred to by their abbreviated name as follow: A. flavocordia, B. frigida, L. fuscobrunnea, L. physciella, L. cancriformis, P. chlorophanum, R. melanophthalma and R. elegans.DNA extraction, amplification and sequencing of fungal and bacterial communitiesFor the amplicon sequencing analyses, three thalli of each species were selected from each location at which the lichen species was collected. Metagenomic DNA extraction was performed on a 0.5 cm2 fragment of the thallus, devoid of any symptoms of external infection or damage, which was removed from the substrate using a sterile razor blade, and transferred into 1.5 ml reaction tubes. The fragments underwent a series of washes: they were rinsed three times for 15 min with sterile water, followed by a 30 min cleaning step using a 2% Tween 80 solution. A final wash was performed for 15 min with sterile water. The DNA extraction from the cleaned fragments followed the CTAB protocol of Cubero et al. (1999), with minor adjustments. Potential contaminants during the DNA extraction process were checked by establishing negative control samples for each lichen species. These negative controls consisted of a 1.5 ml tube kept open during the whole extraction process, and processed in the same way as the lichen samples for the amplification and sequencing steps.To study the diversity of fungal communities, the nuclear ribosomal internal transcribed spacer 1 region (ITS1) was targeted. The ITS1 region was amplified using the barcoded primers ITS1F (CTTGGTCATTTAGAGGAAGTAA) and ITS2 (GCTGCGTTCTTCATCGATGC; White et al., 1990; Smith and Peay, 2014). The PCR amplification protocol for the ITS1 fragments was run with the following condition: an initial denaturation at 94 C for 3 min, followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 94 C for 45 sec, annealing at 55 C for 45 sec, extension at 72 C for 1 min, and a final extension step at 72 C for 5 min.The V4 variable region of the small ribosomal subunit 16S rDNA was used to assess bacterial diversity. This variable region was amplified using the primers F515 (GTGCCAGCMGCCGCGGTAA) and R806 (GGACTACHVGGGTWTCTAAT) as described by Caporaso et al. (2012). The PCR amplification of the V4 variable region was performed with the following protocol: an initial denaturation at 94 C for 3 min, followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 94 C for 45 sec, annealing at 50 C for 1 min, extension at 72 C for 90 sec, and a final extension step at 72 C for 10 mins.Samples were then sequenced in pair ends (2x300 bp) using the Illumina MiSeq platform at the Edmund Mach Foundation (San Michele all'Adige, Italy).

PRJNA991094.title: Arctic and Antarctic PHA producing bacteria
PRJNA991094.description: Microorganisms inhabit almost all available environments on Earth. They owe their successfulcolonizing skills partially to the ability of energy and nutrient providing substance storage. One suchsubstance are the macromolecular polymers called polyhydroxyacids (PHAs), that help survive periodiccarbon deficits but also enable to cope with several types of environmental stresses. Those polymers haverecently gained much attention as an environmentally friendly (biodegradable) alternative for oil-basedplastics.The main objective of this project is to examine the role of bacterial storage materials that arePHAs in adaptation of polar region bacteria to stress conditions but also to evaluate biotechnologicalpotential of those microbes and the PHAs they produce.Bacterial strains from the Arctic and Antarctic Psychrophile (cold-lovers) Collection (part of theCentral Collection of Strains of the Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics, Polish Academy ofSciences) will be screened for PHA production. This collection holds almost 3000 isolates derived fromvarious materials gathered during six expeditions to Arctic and Antarctica. Strains will be examined forPHA granule storage and presence of key PHA synthesis enzyme encoding genes. Genetic and genomicresearch will allow to determine the structure of the whole genetic apparatus encoding the PHA synthesisability in a given strain. Those gene clusters will be introduced into a model microorganism (Escherichiacoli) to further examine PHA influence on bacterial physiology. PHA-positive native and recombinantstrains as well as their PHA-negative mutant equivalents will be subjected to a range of cell damagingphysical and chemical conditions to determine PHA involvement in their survival. Insights into thechemical structure of the polar region bacteria-produced PHAs and its biosynthesis from waste productmaterials, like glycerol, will allow to evaluate their biotechnological potential.The reasons for tackling this specific subject are both scientific (ecologic) and economic. Polarregion bacteria experience a multiple of life-challenging factors in combinations not seen in otherenvironments. This causes an evolutionary emergence of mechanisms enabling growth in such harshcircumstances, like the ability to store and utilize PHAs. Therefore Arctic and Antarctic ecosystems mayhost a plenitude of diverse, stress resistant PHA producers, able to utilize new low temperaturebiosynthesis pathways using unusual carbon sources. The search and comprehensive analyses of suchstrains can prove extremely valuable when seeking to lower bioplastic production costs and raising theirpopularity among consumers.
PRJNA991094.center_name: Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics Polish Academy of Sciences

PRJNA1029732.title: The first scallop-associated chemosynthetic bacterial symbiont
PRJNA1029732.description: No species from the order Pectinida was reported to symbiosis with chemosynthetic bacteria previously. Here, we report the first chemosynthetic bacterium (Proteobacteria: Gammaproteobacteria) associated with a dee-sea scallop Catillopecten margaritatus collected from the Haima seep in the South China Sea.

PRJNA1028309.title: Antarctic krill (E. superba) gut microbiome raw sequence reads
PRJNA1028309.description: The Krill Gut Microbiome Project (KiGuMi) investigates the microbial diversity in the digestive tract of the Antarctic krill, Euphausia superba. Krill contains unique enzymatic capacities that enable highly efficient hydrolytic degradation of phyto- and/or zooplankton-derived, complex substrates such as polysaccharides, proteins and lipids. The microbiome of the E. superba gut has not been studied in detail and represents a thus far untapped marine bioresource for hydrolytic enzymes.Therefore, the aim of the KiGuMi project is to explore the microbial diversity of the krill gut.

PRJNA1023863.title: Bacterial and fungal soil communities of four calcareous glacier forefields in the Alps
PRJNA1023863.description: Bacterial-fungal interactions in recently deglaciated ecosystems promote biogeochemical cycles, mineral soil fertility, and pioneer plant growth, but the diversity of keystone microbes and the quality of their interactions remain largely unexplored. Here, we investigated the diversity of both fungal and bacterial communities to predict core microbial networks and to estimate conserved interactions across comparable deglaciated systems. We studied the soil fungal and bacterial communities at the early stages of soil development (0-25 years ice-free soil) in four receding calcareous glaciers of the Alps (>200 samples). High-resolution marker-gene (16S-V4 and ITS2) sequences were collected.

PRJEB59471.title: Methanotrophs in arctic-alpine soils
PRJEB59471.description: Arctic-alpine ecosystems show a high spatial heterogeneity, which is related to differences in elevation and micro-topographic features like slopes, ridges and depressions. We hypothesize that this spatial variation supports different habitats for aerobic methanotrophic microorganisms due to changes in soil moisture and temperature regimes. We extracted DNA from soil samples taken from two mountain regions in the Norwegian Scandes with strong gradients in micro-topography and elevation. Quantitative PCR and amplicon sequencing of the functional marker gene pmoA was used to investigate differences in methanotrophic abundance and community composition. Additionally, quantification of the methanogenic markergene mcrA was also performed. To explore the effect of long-term temperature and soil moisture regimes on the methanotrophic communities, partial least square regression (PLSR) analysis was performed. We found a higher methanotrophic diversity and abundance in the waterlogged depressions in the low alpine belt.
PRJEB59471.center_name: INRES Molecular Biology of the Rhizosphere

PRJEB66202.title: Annual Dynamics of Bacterial & Archaeal Communities in the West Spitsbergen Current (2019-2020)
